reviewText: Uhhh... Can you say Lois Lane meets Leni Riefenstahl in Laputa? Sky Captain is Joe Sullivan (Jude Law), who flies a vintage Annie Chenault Flying Tiger P-38 modified for aquabatics. His plane's number is h11-od, which makes more sense upside down, as does his girlfriend, Ace reporter Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow), and his other girlfriend with the eyepatch, British dreadnaught Frankie Cook (Angelina Jolie). He's also attracted to a mysterious female assassin (Ling Bai), the swine.Dr. Totenkopf, translateable equally well as either Dr. Skull or Dr. Deadhead (Larry Olivier), is the archvillain whose army of giant flying robots (slightly ahead of their time in 1939 New York) is out to "save" the world from itself, in his own (you guessed it!) dastardly and inimitably twisted way unless you've seen Moonraker.Maybe the only surprise in all this tongue in chic is the sheer mass of compacted cliches, but what makes it interesting to me, at least, is the undeniable fact that this movie is American anime, minus any and all actual animation except for what you see on the screen. The visuals could have been penned by Hayao Miyazaki, but the live action plot is some kind of metaphorically impure Marvel Comics Übermensch fantasy. It's also the first movie I've seen since Der Blaue Engel in which German is spoken without a sneer.The gumsnapping sass is vintage Thirties Hollywood. There's also a Julie Garland walk-on in full Technicolor, as seen on a tiny square screen in one of those enormous Art Deco movie palaces from the period. The rest of this flick is sepia-toned.Four stars for fun, out of five. This is the best B movie since Milky Way went poppable, but you may need an elastic attention span. And grease your suspension of disbelief.
summary: Lois Lane meets Leni Riefenstahl in Laputa

reviewText: Those who love film are going to recognize Sky Captain as a turning point, much as 2001, Star Wars IV and Jurassic Park were turning points.  While computerized special effects and CGI have been tools for decades, in Sky Captain, the director has taken the next step and used CGI to transfer what is in his mind directly to the screen without having to make any compromises regarding locations, sets, weather, and all the other impediments to realizing a vision.  The implications for the artist are staggering, and the fact that the director chose to visit the classic serial genre with all its deco/moderne/expressionist trappings is a bonus.Unfortunately, all this is going to go right by a lot of people, particularly young people (even Star Wars was nearly 30 years ago).  But those who love Metropolis, Buck Rogers, Flash Gordon, King Kong, Lost Horizon, and all the propagada movies and cartoons from the late 30s/early 40s along with modern-day homages to the old-style movie movies such as Raiders of the Lost Ark and Star Wars IV will feel very much at home and will thoroughly understand the soft focus and color palette.I loved every minute of this and will be first in line for the DVD.
summary: A Wow from Beginning to End
Title: N/A

reviewText: Every so often a movie comes out which nearly the whole world seems to love, and I seem to be the only one out there who just doesn't think it's all that great.  Such is the case with SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW.  The previews to this movie made it look like it was going to be one of the best movies to come out this year.  But I found this film to be quite forgettable (in spite of the fact that it does have several genuinely enjoyable parts).The fact of the matter is that SKY CAPTAIN runs away with a plot and does not bother to invite the viewer along.  The storyline is set en media res - a Latin phrase which means "in the middle of things" - implying that there was a lot of previous goings on between the main characters, but these things are told in such a contrived and unoriginal way that I thought I was watching Indiana Jones and Marion Ravenwood duke it out over their bitter affair from yesteryear (reference from RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK).My primary problem with this film is not the unemotional dialogue or the overwhelming amount of CGI (which almost never makes a movie look good) but the fact that the filmmakers could not decide what they wanted this film to be.  It almost works as a vintage throwback to the old classic serials of the 1930s.  It almost works as a comic book come to life.  It almost works as a marvelous special effects show.  It almost works as an Indiana Jones-type thriller (I personally think they were overdoing that one just a tad.)  And it almost works as an artistic cinematic experiment.  But the people who made this film decided to throw all of these ingredients into the same bowl, hoping for the best.  Sometimes a movie can be all of those things, but it's a rarity.  SKY CAPTAIN makes a valiant effort but runs out fuel just short of the landing strip.  Got kids?  Take them to see this movie for some good clean fun.  But don't expect too much substance.
summary: The cinematic equivalent of multiple personality disorder

reviewText: The visual imaages are remarkable.  In fact, they are what is good about the movie.  If viewed for that, it is worth seeing.The story was a major disapointment.  Depite good acting, it was impossible to care about the charaters.  I think this was because the story line drags too much and just seems to be a compendium of  too movie references: for example, the robots were transmogrifications of Gort, Robbie and the Iron Giant but with a bad attitude.  Running around inside the mountain with the rocketship was reminicent of Indiana Jones and James Bond; the splash down sequence was pure Bond. A good idea got out of control. There is actualy a decided absence of new ideas and creativity in this regard. That's understandable for first time directors but the producers have been around long enough to know better and should have exercise more control.The DVD includes the 6 minute short that was the basis of the project.It is actually much better than the film itself.  Had they continued with that and been held to 90 minutes the results could have been impressive.  Also in the special fetures section someone says they were trying for a "noire" look -- and in that may lie another big problems.  It had that look, alright, but there was nothing "noire" about the characters or the story line.  No moral ambiguity about motivations, no sense of emptiness at the end.I hope they get to try again but next time with the help of simeone who can spin a good tight tale and who understands that the visual style must be linked to the stopry and characters.

reviewText: "Sky Captain" was a good movie to watch.  The scenes and images depicted in the movie make for an older person who was a child during the 1930s and 1940s a more delight for that nostalgia of comic book heroes and Hollywood glamor.  Jude Law and Gwenyth Paltrow have good chemistry as one-time lovers who still have feelings for each other.  Polly Perkins is a prototype of Lois Lane and Sky Captain is the equivalency of Superman.  Both have strong feelings for each other but they cannot have a deep and meaningful relationship because he is always out to save the world from crime and she is an ambitious career-minded woman.The movie was entertaining to watch as in sound and graphic effects, costume and set designing, and plot and action.  I have to give Giovanni Ribisi and Angelina Jolie credit for their supporting roles to help Sky Captain save the world from destruction.

reviewText: After hearing all of the anticipation and actually accepting the hype that surrounding the release of this movie to the theatres during the autumn of 2004, I could never get a chance to actually see it on the big screen and thus the movie passed me by for a long afterwards until I rented it on DVD. As painful as it is, I have to be honest with my opinion of "Sky Captain". This movie is completely disappointing in my book. I might not get a lot of support with my review but I stand my ground on this. This is certainly far from being the worst movie by any means so at least try not to view this review as smashing this movie to bits."Sky Captain" is lacking in good storyline and the entire movie meanders in so many directions that it ends up being confusing and hard to enjoy because of this ("Matrix Reloaded and Revolutions" suffers similarly but far less so). The the giant robots are outright ridiculous and almost made me laugh at the way they looked more like something that combined the cartoonish quality of "Inspector Gadget" (a great cartoon series) and some kind of Tomb Raiderish CGI figures. I could understand very much the idea focusing this during the end of the 1930s and early 1940s and such but a lot of the technology and many machines almost make it look like 2050 or 2105 (100 years after writing this review) yet somehow aircraft and other obsolete technology is transported through a time machine and dropped off in the far future. That's what this movie feels more like as opposed to a World War II era storyline.The movie was indeed shot combing live action footage of the cast with all-CGI backgrounds and that is a very interesting new technique. I'm sorry but upon hearing how the special effects were `groundbreaking' I have to disagree with this. Some of the CGI effects are actually very good and are breathtaking in their visual appeal but for the most part, the special effects are actually quite blurry and make the movie difficult to watch. This is one of the things that killed this movie for me. I am all for CGI-effects even if they do get overblown but SKATWOT's special effects are just so overdone, so overproduced, to the point that it saps the quality out of it. The special effects in "Lord of The Rings" and even the Matrix trilogy (including the 1999 original) were far superior to the EFX in "Sky Caption". I did not see much of anything that looked revolutionary or groundbreaking in this movie. What could've been groundbreaking instead comes off as overdone and a grand waste of opportunity.I'm not saying avoid this movie like the plague necessarily but do not expect anything out of the ordinary on this movie. A bitter and crushing disappointment to say the least, you're better off just passing this by.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had read a bunch of online reviews that said this was a movie that was all "look" and little substance.  It's true.  The gauzy, sepia-toned computo-cinematography is equal parts Fritz Lang's Metropolis and cheesy sci-fi serialization.  It's thrilling to look at for the first few minutes, but once the torpor of the film becomes apparent, nothing really makes much of an impression.  It seems as if the stars -- Jude Law and Gwyneth Paltrow -- were instructed to behave as if they were actors in a low-budget '30s action serial, ie., to emote flatly and have delayed or muted reactions to any and all plot developments.  This, combined with the actual challenge of acting against a blue screen (where the actor is told what special effects will be doing, but can't actually see what will be onscreen in final print...), essentially sinks the film.  Overall, the movie is just plain unexciting -- the pacing is slow, the special effects are also held in check, presumably to mimic the stiff, ricketty charm of the serials.  Thus, robots clank past clumsily, stone walls fall to the ground as if made of molasses, airplanes move with mechanical deliberation... Why the director didn't just digitize in some fake "wires" to hold the models up is, honestly, a bit of a mystery to me.  The film is full of clever homages to classic films -- The Wizard Of Oz, Lost Horizon, every "girl reporter" film known to mankind, etc. -- but although it's clearly a labor of love on the part of director Kerry Conran, Sky Captain is essentially dull as dishwater.  It's a pity.  If they had injected just a modicum of excitment into the proceedings, this could have been a wonderful film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As most of this film is shot with the actors reacting to imaginary CGI creations plugged into the movie in post-production, the Director gets all the blame for hiring such a slip-shod Film Editor.  The characters frequently react late to the effects, making them look stupid.  Like saying "Dynamite" when the audience can clearly read the word on many CGI boxes in front of the characters.  Or "We're under water" when we can see that as all too obvious, thank you.  At first, I was laughing at how ridiculous the script seemed to be, but later realized that this really could have been a fun flick to watch with a little more attention to the finer details.  Like the underrated art of Film Editing.  The Art Direction in this film is interesting making all the live action characters look like comic book characters watching hordes of giant robots fly or walk by.  But with so much CGI surrounding the actors, and very little chemistry between the lead actors besides, the film is eventually soulless and two dimensional.  Anyway, this is a passable rental.  It is worth seeing for the look of the film, but the acting is average, the direction is lame, and the film editing is absolutely dreadful.
summary: The actors should not be blamed.

reviewText: If the concept of an action filled comic book style adventure leaves you cold avoid this picture. If it can amuse and entertain you, then this will be satisfying. The characters are consistent, well formed, and authentic within the logic of its generic type; that is, they act logically in terms of the premise. Stunts are quite well done while the hardware is anything but penny-board masquerading as space ships. All looks as it should look in such an adventure. I have no idea of which age and sex groups it will most interest, but is is certain to have wide appeal.
summary: Successful creation of a comic strip adventure

reviewText: EXPERIMENTAL FORMAT DELIVERS THINGS TO COME FOR MOVIE LOVERS,IN A FEW WORDS ----This is a grand but light-hearted spectacle that goes beyond the farthest digital marker and still manages to deliver a story worthy of the epic experimental form.WHAT'S "SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW" ALL ABOUT?:In 2 words -- limitless possibilities. We have a grand story that fully utilizes the enormous scope of this epic digital production. Gwyneth Paltrow and Jude Law interact sensationally with sets that were literally never there. Unfortunately, they get tripped up and bogged down with a lot of mindless, out-of-place banter which gives the impression that there is poor chemistry between the two leads. Nevertheless, a new and exciting digital world has been created by the Conran brothers and they will be back with more for us to behold.This film sets up a very retro yet futuristic atmosphere, very much in the spirit of "Things To Come" which starred Raymond Massey [James Dean's father in East of Eden]. In Sky Captain, however, the universe that Raymond Massey could only hint at in "Things To Come" was actually constructed for us to see through the eyes of Jude Law and Gwyneth Paltrow.Naturally, our heros are fighting against all odds and the ticking clock to save the world. Fortunately, they have all the interesting and amazing gadgets they need to get the job done and amaze us in the process. Just like the sensational serials of the early television age, they offer everything we could want in a visual spectacle: Giant Evil Robots - Mad Scientists - Flying Aircraft Carriers - Fighter Planes that double as submarines - heroines with eyepatches - and some romance thrown in.ABOUT THE DVD:I have the "Special Collector's Edition" - Widescreen. They also offer this edition in "Full-Screen" format, but you can't get both formats in the same set. Having seen the film in both formats, I can't imagine getting the full-screen edition as it does lessen the awe-inspiring impact and the enormous scope of the digital sets. It also tends to break up some of the scenes as this film was clearly meant to be seen in widescreen format.DVD Features:Available Subtitles: English, Spanish; Available Audio Tracks: English (Dolby Digital 5.1), French (Dolby Digital 2.0 Surround); Commentary by producer Jon Avent plus filmmaker Kerry Conran and the VFX crew; "Brave New World" featurette; "The Art of the World of Tomorrow" featurette; The original 6-minute short; Deleted Scene-----*- IF YOU LIKED THIS FILM ALSO CONSIDER SEEING --"The Incredibles", "Mars Attacks", "Superman: the Animated Series" (1940), "SUPERMAN - Mechanical Monsters" (1941), Dave Fleischer, "King of the Rocket Men" - Serial (1949), Fred Brannon.
summary: WONDERFULLY PLEASANT SPECTACLE THAT BE JUST THE FIRST OF MANY SUCH FANTASY EPICS!
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, let's dispense with the plot.It's utterly preposterous, from the notion of flying giant robots to underwater airplanes to the hidden villain "Totenkopf" to rescue pods for the critters sent up on the rocket ark. (Why rescue pods for critters meant never to return to earth?) But then the plots of most of your lighter action/scifi movies are preposterous. Think "National Treasure," any James Bond movie, most Jackie Chan movies. Moreover, "wooden" and "campy" are about the kindest descriptions I can think of for the acting.What makes "Sky Captain" worthwhile is its enthralling reimagining of the Art Deco Manhattan of the 1930s, with its muted colors and grainy film-stock texture. What makes it worthwhile is its bold creation of impossible technology that looks precisely as it should look, given the era in which the story takes place. What makes it worthwhile is its Saturday-matinee energy and optimism; the old can-do Americanism of Doc Savage and his crew. What makes it worthwhile is its verve, dash and over-the-top style.I mean, how brilliant is it to shoot the film in color, convert it to black and white in the computer, and then recolorize it "by hand"? A hand-tinted film!How brilliant is it to resurrect old footage of Laurence Olivier (gone 15 or 20 years now) and convert him into "Totenkopf"?Perhaps the most important thing about this film is what it might lead to. Now entire worlds can be created from pure imagination, a few actors, computer talent and a studio with a giant blue screen.I can't wait to see what Kerry Conran does with Edgar Rice Burroughs' "A Princess of Mars."
Title: N/A

reviewText: In Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow, Director Kerry Conran uses CGI to take us back to the film world of 1939, modeling the action, plot and techology after the Grade B flicks of the time. A P-40 aircraft is specially modified to go under water (shades of Chitty Chitty Bang Bang) and is remarkably a two-seater plane, which is an historical anachronism.Intrepid New York City reporter Polly Perkins, played by Gwyneth Paltrow, is hot on the story of the disappearance of several scientists when an army of robots and flying machines attacks New york. Sky Captain Joe Sullivan, played by Jude Law comes to the rescue.He and Perkins hook up and it seems they have a history. There's an undercurrent of romantic tension but nothing that is inappropriate for kids. They don't even kiss during the movie, although several times it seems as though they will.Giovanni Ribisi plays a technical expert, Dex, who is kidnapped by the enemy when Sky Captain's base is attacked. Polly and Sky Captain set off in pursuit of the baddies, stopping along the way to get some help from British commander "Frankie", played by Angelina Jolie and with whom Sky Captain also has a past.Sky Captain and Polly end up in Nepal where they find the lost city of Shangri-La and discover that the mad scientist is building a space ship ark because he believes earth is doomed and he wants to save the creatures of the world. (there's a really funny visual of a cow in a space capsule!) However, if the spaceship blasts off, it will destroy the earth.Sky Captain and Polly meet up again with Dex and find the missing scientists. Along the way there is a lot of humourous dialogue between the three of them, and several tributes to other movies such as Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade and The Empire Strikes Back.This is not a movie to be taken seriously. It's as though an old Buck Rogers movie has been restored to pristine condition, complete with ray guns, although surprisingly these ray guns actually destroy the robots so the movie has to employ various ploys to deprive Sky Captain of his ray gun.My family and I thoroughly enjoyed watching the movie and making fun of the anachronisms, the spurious plot devices and the dialogue. This is not meant to disparage the movie because all of these are intentional on the part of the director. Don't take the movie seriously, just watch it and have fun!
summary: Fun Movie to Make Fun Of

reviewText: I hadn't watched this in years & well I have to admit, this movie is right up my alley, I very much enjoyed it for many reasons. I love the visualization, the scenery, the atmosphere, the fact that it is a movie based on the Golden Era of movies, as if it was shot in the 1930s, it was like an action adventure film noir meets Jurassic park and the Iron Giant. I loved the giant robots & the dino creatures in this. The story has Jude Law as Sky Captain along with Gwyneth Paltow and Angelia Jolie trying to save the world from a mad scientist. Ok its a little deeper than that, but for me it was the action,all the great scenery of where this chase goes from the city to ice to underwater to the jungle. It was also like an Indiana Jones movie too. It had everything needed to entertain, had a lot of action, acting was fine but these movies are made for non stop thrills and this delivered. I do have a passion for giant monsters,robots and great atmospheric scenery,so if you are the same, I highly recommend this movie. It is a lot of fun and a good mix of genres.
summary: Excellent retro science fiction adventure movie !

reviewText: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow is a homage to the "air comics" of the '40s, in which daring aviators battled dastardly villains, the fate of the free world - and sometimes just the world - resting in their sure and steady hands. Parts of this movie are absolute delights for fans of the old air comics. Spotting the influences is fun. Jude Law plays H. Jospeh "Joe" Sullivan, the Sky Captain, leader of a band of mercenary - though America friendly, of course - airmen, obviously inspired by the Blackhawks, a very popular comic of the '40s (and even later though not so popular) about a band of mercenary - though America friendly, of course - airmen. The enemy aircraft with hinged, flapping wings remind one of Birdy, the batwing airplane from Airboy. One of the movie's most elegant images, a flying aircraft carrier, comes from a somewhat later comic, the '60s Nick Fury, Agent of SHIELD.All the backgrounds in this film are CGI. It works. The imagery is convincing, imaginative, and beautiful. The entire movie is set in pastel tones that, while not technically black and white, evoke the feel of an old black and white movie. This almost monochrome look makes the few spots of color, like Polly Perkins' lipstick, the Union Jack on Franky Cook's ship, etc. really stand out. Visually it's hard to fault this movie.The worst thing you can say about SC&TWOT; (that cost it a full two stars with me) is that its two main characters are weak. Though I like Jude Law as an actor, and I'm happy to see his recent success, he simply comes across as too pretty and wimpy to be a tough-as-nails leader of men like Joe Sullivan. This role calls for an actor with the charisma and roguish charm of a young Harrison Ford, and Jude Law ain't it. Reporter Polly Perkins is simply a....well, you know that word that begins with "b" and rhymes with witch? She's self-centered, deceitful, untrustworthy, a serial liar, pushy, verbally and even physically abusive, and impossible to like, sympathize with, root for, or even enjoy her company for any extended period of time. Joe Sullivan has to have a hole in his head for (a) taking her along on this adventure - she nearly gets him killed, again and again, and (b) finding her attractive. I mean, really, all this woman has going for her as a human being is that she looks exactly like Gwyneth Paltrow. As I said earlier, it's hard to fault this movie visually - the filmmakers just needed to put more interesting, admirable people in front of all the pretty pictures.The good news here is Angelina Jolie as Commander Francesca "Franky" Cook, a British fighter jock/commander of the aforementioned flying aircraft carrier who comes to Joe and Polly's aid. Angelina-as-Franky has more charisma and cool than Joe and Polly put together - and she pulls off the Brit accent well. Franky Cook is distilled grace under pressure, a take charge officer, but still so all about loving adventure she has a little girl grin for Joe just before they take off into danger. Given the option of Polly or Franky, only a fool would choose the former. And Angelina Jolie looks great in Franky Cook's head-to-toe black uniform. Franky Cook was obviously inspired by a '40s air comic character called the Black Angel, a gorgeous raven-haired female British fighter pilot who dressed all in black. Replace the Black Angel's hood with a black eye patch and you've got Franky Cook.Unfortunately Franky's not in that much of the movie, then it's back to more witchy Polly and wimpy Joe. If ever there's a sequel to Sky Captain, it should be called Sky Commander and focus on one Commander Franky Cook, aka Angelina Jolie.

reviewText: to me this story seemed like the kind of comic book the would have been written in the 50s.  except for the fact that i think this movie really empowers its female characters more than would have been normal in the 50s.  you have the character polly perkins as a perky newspaper writer who never backs down from a challenge or from anything that keeps her from her story.  she has a history with the male hero of the story, joseph sullivan.  this is the world class flying ace that will set out to save the world.  he is a great hero and like all great heroes he saves the day.  then there is the character of frankie of the british forces, coolly played by angelina jolie (she looks great in an eye patch and with a british accent).  all the characters are sterotypes, but they are stereotypes that people get behind and believe in.  also i think this movie is heavily influenced by war of the worlds except this on is updated.  instead of aliens to fight there are giant robots that terrorize the city.  there are even parts where it sounds like the war of the worlds.  the movie is very grainy almost as if it were shot in the 50s and it was like a classic film noir kind of picture.  all of the actors emote well in front of a blue screen and they are only half of the wonder of this movie.  the graphics of the movie really are quite amazing and often times really seem life like.  the movie contains great action sequences in the sky and under water.  some of the chases really do keep you on the edge of your seat.  then there is also the love story between joe and polly.  and the love story really provides all of the humor found within the movie.  there are some very funny parts within the movie especially when frankie asks joe about polly and she is refferred to as "that".  go see the movie it is visually great with great action and a great story.
summary: A MOVIE THAT PLAYS LIKE A COMIC BOOK READING

reviewText: When I was about ten years old I was really into old time radio serials, and stories of high adventure. Ovalteen's Captain Midnight was one of my very early childhood heroes. I would read his adventures in old 1940s magazines and thrill to the cliffhanger radio shows that played every Saturday of my early youth. I tell you this because back in March 2004 I saw a preview for a film called "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow". I was extremely excited about this movie, as it looks to have taken its style from the 1940s adventures I knew so well. The movie was slated to come out in June. It got pushed back, and early rumors stated it was because the studio had lost faith in the movie. People were saying that it was going to bomb, better left for a home video release. Fearing another disappointment like Mars Attacks years earlier I avoided as much press and internet coverage of the film as I could; getting my only dose of the movie from the odd film trailer I got to sit through.  When I got to see it the world stopped. The movie started and there I was at age ten again. Sure the names had been changed, but all the familiar characters were there, as were all the perilous dangers. For two hours I sat open mouthed as this celluloid memory of childhood un-spooled before me. It was all there, and it was all just as I remember picturing it in my head. The daring dog fights, the ace reporter needing a scoop. Evil henchmen, strange enemy ships, the nick of time rescues, and those cliffhangers played out in a never ending array of dazzling episodes that looked as if they were taken directly off the covers of those 1940's magazines. As the film ended I could not help but feel a slight ting of sorrow, because I was 29 again. There is no episode next Saturday to start a new adventure. All I can do I go back and watch it all over again. Will I be ten again next time I see it? Probably not, but I will be remembering ten again, and looking at it with a more critical eye this next time as one does when one gets older. Will I enjoy it as much? More then I can say. This is a film that did what it set out to do and did not stray from its goal. A great escape into the past that lies just a few years into the future beyond childhood.
summary: A movie to turn into a kid again with

reviewText: This 2004 film reflects amazing visual invention, and first-time writer/director Kerry Conran, self-professed computer geek, has fashioned something remarkably singular from his fertile imagination, his obviously encyclopedic knowledge of pre-WWII popular culture, and most of all, his technological savvy. What he has created is impressive - a self-contained world of startling images that seem simultaneously futuristic and retro in a colorized black-and-white world bathed in diffuse lighting and stylized art deco designs. Moving like a speeding train, the plot is stuffed with so many references to other classic stories and movies it often gets overwhelming, and I have to admit some of the turns get very convoluted as a result. As a pop culture junkie myself, I see tributes to George Pal'sThe War of the Worlds, Ray Harryhausen's special effects inJason and the Argonauts, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle'sThe Lost World, James Hilton'sLost Horizon, Aldous Huxley'sBrave New World, Steven Spielberg'sIndiana Jonestrilogy and "Close Encounters of the Third Kind", George Lucas'Star Warsespecially in the aerial chase scenes, and the stiff upper lip of British WWII films.That's a lot of references for a 103-minute film, sometimes too much, but Conran does a mostly smart job of spinning his plates into a truly exciting film. Beyond that, it amazes me that most of the action was done against a green screen, as the people and images seamlessly meld together. There are incredible sequences involving gigantic robots trampling New York, fanciful aerial air strips with dozens of fighter planes, swarms of automated winged weapons among others, and they are sequenced at a lightning-fast pace. The actors are well cast, though the best compliment one can pay them is that they don't get in the way of the action. In fact, their relative nonchalance to the extraordinary things going on around them is a major part of the fun. Jude Law cuts a dashing figure as the nominal hero, although he seems too lightweight and frankly a bit too earnest to be truly memorable. Gwyneth Paltrow plays the obligatory Lois Lane part, aptly named Polly Perkins, with a saucy mix of Veronica Lake's peek-a-boo allure (I love the skirt slitting shot) and Barbara Stanwyck's tough-dame savvy.In an all-too-brief part late in the film, Angelina Jolie is wonderfully gutsy as a veddy British naval captain, finally able to use her striking looks (not to mention her arresting eyepatch) to great effect. Not every actress can get away with a line like "Alert the amphibious squad!". In smaller roles, Giovanni Ribisi as the bubblegum-chewing Dex and British comedian Omid Djalili as Vienna sausage-loving Kaji seem to function purely as plot devices to move the story along. Conran understandably uses characters as chess pieces because the visual elements are what make this story percolate. I only wish Conran could have simplified the story a bit to let us absorb more of what's going on. I felt a little out of breath every time the locale changed since I wasn't sure I grasped everything I needed to know up to that point. I also think it's a bit of a conceit to "cast" the late Laurence Olivier as the primary villain since it feeds into one of the final plot twists.The 2005 Special Collector's Edition DVD boasts some significant extras starting with two separate commentary tracks - the first from producer Jon Avnet and the second from Conran and the special effects crew. I found there was not enough distinction between the two tracks, but both discuss the complexity of the production in thorough detail. There is a behind-the-scenes documentary, "Brave New World", which runs nearly an hour and shows the startling green screen process. The film was shot on just one soundstage even though the story travels around the world. Two shorts are also included - one focused on the costumes and production design by the director's brother Kevin and the other the six-minute demo made to give studio executives a preview of the final film. Deleted/extended scenes and a gag reel round out the extras.
summary: Incredible Visual Invention in an Overabundant Story

reviewText: "Sky Captain And the World of Tomorrow" is a wonderfully entertaining and refreshingly unique action flick that stands head and shoulders over any other recent films of the genre.  I was stunned by the lush visuals, gorgeous lighting, period costumes, rich colors and overall style of the film.  Whoever said style over substance was a bad thing?"Sky Captain" is riddled with references to films of the 30's and 40's and old adventure comic books.  This nostalgia is what gives "Sky Captain" its own unique persona that has so amazed critics and audiences worldwide.  In the troubled world we live in today, many yearn for simpler times, and the best way to revisit the past is, of course, through film.  In "Sky Captain", I fond comfort in the simplistic beauty of times past.From the opening moments, as snow falls on a Gotham-like a scene, Director Kerry Conran sets the mood and style as he docks the massive airship Hindenburg III to the top of the Empire State Building in a sequence so astounding and breathtakingly real; so of the moment, that it fills audiences with an awe and wonder.  Conran takes a palpable joy in his filmmaking, an enthusiasm that sweeps you off your feet.  The visuals in "Sky Captain" are, simply put, are among the most astounding I have ever seen in a film.  No wonder Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Angelina Jolie and Giovanni Ribisi were all scrambling to be a part of this soon-to-be classic film!The story is by no means bad, as it has been suggested by many, but rather it is much more basic than most action flicks nowadays.  Frankly, I loved the simplicity of the story, which once again reminded me of Old Hollywood.  There were no annoying, pointless subplots that so confused me that I found myself frustrated with the film as I left the theater.  The fun, witty script kept me entertained and I found that I had a large, goofy grin on my face practically the entire film.  The whole thing was just so darn fun and lovable that I couldn't help it!  By far the year's best film.
summary: "The Battle for Tomorrow is About to Begin..."
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had good expectations for "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" and was looking forward to seeing it ever since I saw the first preview. It seemed like a highly original, entertaining flick with a great story to go along. While it definitely succeeds with the former, it fails big time with the latter.This movie has some of the coolest, most innovative special effects you'll ever see, there's no question about that. I was nothing short of impressed with the CGI, not to mention the cool "retro" look portraying a futuristic society in the 1930's. Basically, this movie had everything it needed to be great: an all-star cast, big budget and stunning visuals. But unfortunately, a lousy script and hollow story take away its full potential, to the point where it cannot be overlooked. Let's start with the script. There were several instances where people in the audience laughed out loud at the contrived, silly dialogue from the characters. Not all the script was bad; but what wasn't downright lame was only mediocre, so that's not saying much. And then there's the story. Equally as mediocre and uninspiring. Everyone is a cardboard cut-out. The audience is never given the chance to really care about them. Just when you think there might be some character development, a CGI battle sequence comes into play. They were certainly impressive, but there has to be a balance somewhere. And oh yeah, there's also some shameless product placement (Coca-Cola and Wrigley's chewing gum, I think Double Bubble as well) although it's not as bad as "I, Robot."In terms of performances, everyone is adequate, considering that they were simply "acting" in front of a blue screen. The always reliable Jude Law does the best he can with the script he's given to work with. Gwyneth Paltrow is also good although her performance comes across as campy at times. Angelina Jolie phoned this one in, that is, during the whopping 15 minutes that she's actually in the movie. So for any Jolie fans, know that you won't get to see much of her.I wanted to like "Sky Captain" a lot more than I did. I'm a fan of every actor and was hoping that they could carry it. But the lack of an intriguing plot and disposable script were a disappointment. This movie plays out more like a comic book, and perhaps that's what it should have been instead. It's got plenty of excellent eye candy, and if that's the only reason you go to movies then you'll surely enjoy it. But for anyone else who expects and hopes for a good story to go along with it, you'll probably leave the theater feeling uninspired. "Sky Captain" is not a bad movie, far from it. It has its merits. It's just not as good as it could have been, with all it had going for it.
summary: A deluge of CGI but only a tiny droplet of story and plot

reviewText: Based on the trailers for this film and the reviews I expected to dislike this movie intensely.  I usually hate CGI stuff but it works here: essentially everthing in the movie is CGI, except the actors, and so they avoided 2 major problems with CGI.  CGI tends to be very unnatural when they try to use it to create people, just look at the Spiderman movies.  And when they use CGI to just past an image on the screen, like the fighter plane in the last `Die Hard' movie, then it looks hokey as well.  But in this case the CGI is used to create an entire imaginary world.This film takes place in a retro-fantasy world, which somehow makes it possible to believe the impossible machines and action and improbable characters.  As a fan of old movie serials, 1950's scifi, George Reeves, Buster Crabbe, Clayton Moore, cartoons, and comic books, this movie is as close to tailor-made for me as will ever be.  People with similar interests should not hesitate to see this movie, and try to count every homage or reference to a cartoon, comic strip, or movie serial.A few posters have criticized this film regarding a lack of character growth, blah blah blah.  Well, this is not a movie for those who want hand-wringing angst or the ambivalent meanderings of modern relationships.  This is an escapist adventure, where the story and the action are paramount, and the great mysteries of the human condition are below the surface, only occasionally hinted at.  You want that other stuff go see `Mystic River.'Jude Law doesn't have the appeal of George Reeves, Clayton Moore, or Buster Crabbe, but in this context he comes across as a very suitable hero, a sort of poor man's Indiana Jones.  His character is clearly a ripoff/homage to the great comic book hero of World War II, Blackhawk, and as such he does a good job.  Gwynneth Palterow is easy on the eyes and does an adequate job but is just nowhere near as compelling as Phyllis Coates, Noel Niell, or Jean Rogers were in similar roles.This movie is more of an adventure film than a modern `action film,' which is, IMO, a good thing.  Also, the climactic sequence gives you more to ponder than most modern adventures, and thus has a bigger payoff.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I give this thumbs down, because it's uninspiring in every way but one.As a technical achievement, Sky Captain is everything the producers hoped for, I'm sure. What was it exactly they were trying to achieve? Using computer animation, they've produced what looks like an old black-and-white vaseline-on-the-lens live-action Saturday afternoon popcorn flick made in the 1940s, subsequently given a bad colorization job by Ted Turner. Yes, the color, such as it is, is truly horrid. Old movies never looked like this -- so I really don't know why the visual designers made the color choices they did. Mainly, the film is black and white and gray and a kind of sickly washed-out orange. Bleah.The scale of production, with flying aircraft carriers, secret islands full of fantastic creatures, Shangri-La, gigantic retro-style space rockets, six-story robots marching down the streets of New York City wreaking havoc, is as large as one can imagine. And all this is generated in the computer. The actors were on a soundstage, surrounded by backgrounds and foregrounds covered in blue -- the blue parts being later removed by color separation and replaced with buildings, sky, military control centers, caves, or whatever the scene required. The integration between live and animated is virtually seemless -- probably the best that has ever been achieved.As a viewer, I found the story and characters two-dimensional, and frankly I was continually distracted by the visual style of the film. This two-dimensionality might have been better served, at much less expense, with conventional animation, perhaps in the art deco style of the Batman animated TV series and their subsequent straight-to-video motion pictures (Mask of the Phantasm, Batman and Mr. Freeze, The Batman-Superman Movie) -- I might have enjoyed that kind of film a bit more, if only through lowered expectations.The story itself is a blend of Buck Rogers and early 1950's sci-fi with a dash of James Bond. The dialogue is tolerable as a vehicle to move the story forward, but tries too hard to be clever. Or maybe, when you think about it, it doesn't try hard enouh. So much of the writing in old movies was rather poor -- today we only remember the good stuff, but most of it was pretty bad -- and I see no reason to emulate that cheesiness in a movie produced in 2004.I can't fault the actors for falling flat. Given the lines they had to read, and the fact they had no visual cues from their surroundings to work with, their failure is excusable. Any movie that ends with the line, "Lens cap," obviously has serious problems with the script.The average Adam Sandler movie will move me more than this film did, and that ain't sayin' much. Like a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury (in this case beautifully animated sound and fury), signifying nothing, this film is a failure, but a spectacular failure. But yeah, they did save the world, and Sky Captain gets the girl. But you already knew that's how it would end.
summary: Sky Captain and the sickly faded-orange faces of tomorrow

reviewText: I had only two gripes with the film. One was the quirky pacing of the film, and the somewhat thin performance of Angelina Jolie. But that's about it. I did love the visuals in the film. It's filled with dazzling special effects, lovely music, and gorgeous scenery. The late 30's comic and pulp atmosphere is mixed with modern (50's, 60's and today) sci-fi technologies. I think that's what makes it so appealing: this is an excellent mixture of old and new. Jude Law and Gwyneth Paltrow are both great in this film; the supporting cast is also very good. But the best things about this film are the visual effects, the cinematography, and the stylish art direction. Watch it for the visuals.Grade: A-

reviewText: This film is an interesting mix of pre-World War II characters, reminding the viewer of entertaining cartoon-like creations. It has futuristic high tech science blended with the menace and threat of an evil scientist who is bent on destroying the world as we know it. The primary settings are: a huge city, very much like New York ... a distant unnamed island where on-going research is done by the "good guys" who have captured the giant "robots" which arrive unexpectedly and threaten the population. Later the Sky Captain and Polly Perkins the reporter explore the Himalayas specifically Shambala or Shangri-La ... because of a secret map which Polly obtained ... and due to hints left by Dexter, one of the 'good guy' researchers. They are at some point rescued by "Frankie" who it turns out is an ace pilot. Angelie Jolie very adeptly plays Frankie who is really "Franceska" ...Polly Perkins (Gweneth Paltrow) is a highly engaging news reporter who takes great risks to get the "scoop" of a lifetime. She couragously tracks the giant robots to write the first newspaper story about this major threat facing the population of the city. She receives a phone call to meet a scientist at the theater. He hints of secret experiments which occurred somewhere in Germany done by a scientist which are similar to the high tech threats facing the city. The good scientist disappears ... she fears he is murdered for "knowing too much" and passing it on to her. Before he died, he entrusted her with some valuable documents ... their value becomes known only later after Polly combines her efforts with the Sky Captain. The Sky Captain (played by Jude Law) zooms into view while the giant robots roam the city destroying whatever is in their path ... He flys adroitly between them, among them, adn between sky scrapers and buildings ... risking his life to discover what signals make them work. Eventually, he and Polly exchange information and reluctantly become allies in searching for the truth which lies behind the baffling robotic life-threatening menace. They have a history together ... were considered a romantic item ... but do not entirely trust each other due to some perceived let downs by each. One or the other generally holds back vital information even as they pair up to seek the truth ... It is clear from their exchanges that the film will be enjoyable and sparkling. The energy dynamics of the personalities of the characters are magnetic ... The film promises to be entertaining by the eclectic mix of unique settings, creative use of sci-fi, and the unique and complex plot that unfolds. At times there is a Matrix-like feel to the film ... the Tibetan scenes are well done. This viewer was entertained from beginning to end by the odd twists and turns of the plot which led to a climax and explosive conclusion. Erika Borsos (erikab93)
summary: Eclectic Mix of High Tech, WWII, Comic Characters & Tibet

reviewText: I was reminded of this movie after a discussion on most disappointing movies you have ever seen.Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow is one of the few movies I have ever had to turn off with in the first 25 minutes because it was so painful to watch. The dialogue is beyond horrible and the acting is even worse, (which has to be the fault of the director, because many of the actors in this flick have shown elsewhere that they can act).Now, realize, that I am a Sci-fi fan and will often watch even some very low budget stuff, if it can provide at least some hook to overcome it's shortcomings. I've also enjoyed other movies with a very retro 50's style delivery, overdone special effects, etc... So, no negative bias towards the genre or the concept; I just found this movie to be as grating as fingernails on a chalkboard.Another reviewer said it was better to watch this one with the sound off, because the dialogue was so bad. To bad I hadn't thought of that, maybe I could have given a more in depth review of the movie and possibly have found something positive to say about the visuals. (For the record though, the blurry soft focus evident in the bit of the movie I was able to get through was almost as annoying as the dialogue)!Everyone is different. Some people gave this thing positive reviews, so maybe you'll like it too. However, just be warned that if you have never seen this movie before and still feel you want to give it a shot, you might want to rent it before deciding if it's worth a purchase!
summary: Worst big budget movie I have ever seen!

reviewText: Not since The Fifth Element has a film combined state-of-the-art effects with an original and captivating storyline.  Many people were expecting another rendition of Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within, and I hope they're pleasantly surprised.  Without question, Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow looks great.  The CG sets looked real and authentic and the actor truly appear to be inhabiting this virtual world.The story is very fast-paced as well as intriguing and captivating.  It reminded me of the Indiana Jones films.  But the biggest surprise here is the brilliant job Jude Law and Gwyneth Paltrow did...especially Gwyneth.  She truly looks, acts and sounds the part of a 1930's reporter.  Angelina Jolie's role is fun and spunky, but unfortunately it's more of a glorified cameo role.  I'm sure there'll be a sequel and hopefully we'll see more of her character.There was not one moment in the film where I was bored.  This is a film for people who are looking for entertainment, which it delivers in truckloads.  I recommend it to anyone and I truly hope it fares well in theaters.  It certainly deserves it!

reviewText: Computer generated special effects have been around for quite some time now, and often questionably so, but they come into their own with Kerry Conran's SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW--an innovative film that failed in theatrical release but which now makes a big splash in the home market.  And whether you love it or hate it, SKY CAPTAIN is likely to cast a very long shadow indeed.As a concept, the film seems to be based on the popular serials of the 1930s and 1940s.  This is not limited to the use of an improbable plot fueled by special effects and cliffhanger action sequences, but it extends to the dialogue and characters as well, all of which are typical of such celebrated serials as BUCK ROGERS, CAPTAIN MARVEL, SPY SMASHER, and THE CRIMSON GHOST. The film also draws specific plot elements from such diverse sources as KING KONG, LOST HORIZON, THE WIZARD OF OZ, and WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE, to name but a few.The story is typical of serials.  "Girl Reporter" Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow) is doing a story on missing scientists--and when giant metal robots attack New York she unexpectedly holds a clue to their origin.  She and Sky Captain (Jude Law) form an uneasy alliance to get to the bottom of things. With an assist from Sky Captain's faithful sidekick Dex (Giovanni Ribisi) and the disconcertingly military Frankie (Angelina Jolie), the two search the world--and finally track the wicked Dr. Totenkopf (Laurence Olivier, resurrected via CGI) to his secret lair.The look of the film follows suit.  The live cast worked on a blue screen set, and with the exception of a single set, the costumes, and items the live actors had to handle, everything you see on the screen was created in the computer and added after the fact.  A great many people have described the look of the film as "deco," an arts movement associated with the 1920s; this is misleading.  It would be more accurate to describe it as a mixture of pre-WWII arts movements filtered through a 1950s sensibility, and the result is like nothing so much as a pulp science fiction magazine cover unexpectedly come to life.Now, how much you like this will depend to a great extent on how clearly you recognize the film styles and specific films that have clearly influenced it.  If you know nothing about serials, for example, you are likely to be appalled by the flatness of the script and Paltrow's one-note performance; on the other hand, if you are a serial fan, you'll immediately recognize that the script is reflective of such serials as SPY SMASHER and that Paltrow echoes Linda Sterling, famous for such serials as THE CRIMSON GHOST.  It wouldn't be too much to say that in many respects SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW is akin to an inside joke.But most particularly, your liking for this film will depend on how you react to the visuals.  I am not a great fan of CGI when it is used to bolster live action films such as GLADIATOR or TITANIC; I can usually spot the CGI and I find it distracting.  But I have to come down in favor of SKY CAPTAIN: this isn't an effort to "make it look real;" this is an effort to make a totally artificial world, and whether it be giant robots, Shangri-La, or Radio City Music Hall the designs are stunning and remarkably well executed.  Whatever other shortcomings it may have, SKY CAPTAIN has incredible visual "WOW!"The DVD release is visually handsome with superior sound, and the package contains a fair number of bonuses.  Unfortunately, the two commentary tracks are less interesting than you might expect, but two short documentaries ("Brave New World" and "The Art of the World of Tomorrow") are quite good--and the original six minute short that inspired the film is fascinating.  Not every one will get it, so I recommend you rent before you buy, but on the whole this is a show truly worth the money.  Recommended.GFT, Amazon Reviewer
summary: Fascinating Visuals in CGI Hommage to Serial Cinema

reviewText: The future is now people, and with "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" director Kerry Conran is determined to make sure that we know it.  Using artificial sets and spectacular CGI, the first-time filmmaker delivers an adventure that's too big to be real."Sky Captain" begins with a bang and never lets up. Giant-sized robots descend upon 1930's New York City, destroying anything in their path.  The robots are sent to kidnap scientists and machinery needed by the evil Dr. Totenkopf.  It's up to Joe "Sky Captain" Sullivan to stop the rampage.  When his inventor sidekick (Giovanni Ribisi, is also kidnapped, he teams up with ace reporter and ex-flame Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow) to save the day.What makes "Sky Captain" so great is the love and effort Conran put into this movie.  This is his first feature film, but it's better than half of the movies that have been released within the past five years.  The action is fast but you are still able to tell what's going on.  There are no fancy edits or slow-motion bullet time, yet even the most attention deficit viewers shouldn't have a problem keeping their eyes on the screen.This film will be remembered mostly for being the first to be shot entirely in front of a blue screen.  None of the sets are real.  Conran filmed the actors and then spent several years working on the rest of the film, adding in everything else.  We've seen this kind of thing before, most notably in the "Star Wars" prequels, but never to this extent.  The robots, the cityscape, the cars, almost everything is CGI.  Even the actor who plays the film's villain is a special effect as he's played by Laurence Olivier, who died in 1989.  While there are a few shots where the blue screen technique is quite obvious, the final product shows that there was some real talent behind the effects work.  Though they don't look photo realistic, the effects create an alternate world that's easy to fall into.Like most big effects pictures, the plot comes second.  In this case, however, this isn't such a bad thing.  "Sky Captain's" story comes straight out of the pulp, sci-fi tales of yesteryear.  It's nothing but pure escapism and doesn't need to be complicated.  Conran, who also wrote the script, knows his stuff and keeps the film in homage territory without turning it into one big rip-off.  The one big flaw of "Sky Captain" is that the characters are almost as simple as the story.  We are given very little history on Joe Sullivan.  He's a hero because the filmmakers need him to be.  He lacks the in-depth persona or background story of such great adventures as Han Solo or Indiana Jones.  Polly Perkins isn't afraid to get the story, but we don't know why she's so driven.  Though they seem a little empty, the characters are still likeable, especially Franky Cook (Angelina Jolie), who should really appeal to fans of Marvel Comics' Nick Fury.Many have said that "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" is the new "Star Wars" or "Indiana Jones".  It's not, but it comes pretty close.  If a future episode gives us a little more character this will be the new adventure epic that fans of the genre have been waiting for.RATING:  A- or 4  out of 5 stars

reviewText: This film is the outgrowth of an idea that began on a computer, which took ten years to materialize, and that quite by accident.The concept was to create backgrounds apart from the actors, use green screen and minimal set dressing to "set the mood" of the environment, and then have the actors run around in what appears to be huge factories, mountain lairs,and the like, without trying to seem "hyper real", almost in an anit-CGI way, while using CGI to create a very highly stylized look to the film - well, this film anyway, which is designed to play like the old matinee movie serials from the 1940s.To me, it succeeds. The "science" isn't explained - who cares - and the characters have "pasts", some of which matter to the story, others just to flesh out relationships... convenience things. And the story is "fantastical", as all sci-fi serial stories should be.And I loved it. I was a kid again, in the darkened theatre enjoying the adventure of it all. It was a breath of fresh air to me.I can grow weary of too much hyper realism (Avatar) and exposition (Prometheus) about the science of a thing in sci-fi movies/stories. Sometimes I don't want you to explain the technology... just use it! Example: the only explanation regarding the light sabre is that it was a weapon from a more civilized time, and we never learned how it works, just what it can do. They didn't explain how ships moved through space, either. They just did and we accepted it!Now, my problem. It isn't with the film. It's not "believable", it's not supposed to be. The problem is that I would have loved to have seen a couple more stories in the Sky Captain universe; but alas, nothing came of it. The actors chosen would have been happy to do a sequence of films. They weren't "big budget" affairs, could be made easily enough, and if the stories were equal to this one, we would have loved them - even if they went straight to DVD... or became a TV series (which would have been well within any budget to do).I miss the days when sci-fi movies just told a great story and we didn't wonder too much about the "science" involved; and we really didn't care that it wasn't very "realistic" either.

reviewText: As a kid in the '60s, I used to watch the old sci-fi serials from my parents childhoods. Buck Rogers Flash Gordon etc, they were hokey even by that time, but still a lot of fun.This week I had some time to kill, so I put in my DVD ofSky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (Widescreen Special Collector's Edition)and like those old serials it was fun, and corny, but unlike those old movie shorts it has Angelina Jolie, and Gwyneth Paltro (playing strong women), and some very cool CG animations that the old movies couldn't even imagine.So here's the deal, this is not what we expect in modern sci-fi, but if you are in the mood for something fun with some old time flavor, Sky Captain should do just fine!

reviewText: I looked forward with great anticipation to seeing "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" after having read mostly glowing reviews from the critics.  Alas, I was disappointed in this film.  While it is beautiful to look at, "Sky Captain" has no soul.The storyline is mostly a conglomeration of movie serials and landmark films from the 1920s and 1930s, and there are many none-too-subtle homages to Metropolis, King Kong, Buck Rodgers, and even a small tip of the hat to Godzilla (one must look closely to see the latter).  There are also influences from 1950s films; the giant robots bear a striking resemblance to the machine from the film "Kronos", complete with antenna, circular radio waves and sound.The actors are of quality background, but something is missing in terms of chemistry between the two principals.  Sky Captain (Jude Law) flies around in a souped-up P-40 Warhawk fighter plane, and is joined in his adventures by Ace Reporter Polly Perkins (Gwyeth Paltrow).  Polly spends most of the film whining about this or that, and Paltrow seems a bit overwhelmed by all the bluescreens; perhaps this is because she has not worked in this kind of film before, while Law did extensive duty in an effects-loaded "A.I. Artificial Intelligence".  These two have worked together before (The Talented Mr. Ripley) with excellent results, but there is no real warmth between them in this film.  Angelina Jolie appears all too briefly as the British commander of a sort of flying aircraft carrier.The production design and extensive CGI effects are truly amazing, with art-deco elements throughout.  In this respect the film is a work of art, with film noir lighting even in what is supposed to be broad daylight.  One major glitch in the film in light of this is the fact that Polly takes photos in caves, deep shadows, etc. without any semblance of a flash-filmmakers who specialize in such things as lighting should certainly know better.Overall "Sky Captain" does have a unique look about it; I can't say I've seen a modern movie that captures the visual essence of the 1920/30s like this film does.  However, the plot is far too convoluted (simple plots being the basis of the old serials), and some of the actors seem overwhelmed by the CGI technology.  Their chops suffer somewhat as a result.  2 stars for technical achievment.

reviewText: This is a film that is set in an amorphous era highly suggestive of WWII, with subject matter and imagery  (Robots) from 1930's to 1950s Sci Fi, and the look of a silent era film, most often "Metropolis".  1940's film quality and cinematography were much better than this, but it works, so who cares?  The dialog is snappy and there's actually a rather involved story that caught me by surprise.  All in all it was very entertaining even if some of it was patently unbelievable.  Ah well.  The mystery is how this didn't become a series, and it would be very nice for tv.
summary: Extravagantly Derivative, Entertaining and Fun To Watch

reviewText: Okay I wont bore you with the plot (you've seen it all before anyway) or go into how new this films looks instead I warn anyone over 16 to stay away. Rent the first Indian Jones movie if you are in the mood for a good circa 1939 adventure. There is absolutely nothing new to discover in this flick. The pacing is dreary as well as the fuzzy CGI look to this thing. It's like watching a movie in your bathroom mirror after taking a hot shower. Instead of having fun with cliché's this movie depends on them to tell us about the characters past relationships and motivations. the dialogue is never witty or clever and rings false from the flat Gwyneth Paltrow, Jude Law is two dimensional as well and lacks on butchness.  Really this is a movie for kids only and will put adults to sleep. The only moment worth watching here is the scene inside of Radio City Music Hall. Two characters are having a secret meeting with the Wizard of Oz in playing in front of them. The Wizard of Oz, now that's how to make a movie.

reviewText: I didn't rush to see this movie, and was glad I didn't stand in the queue for its preview!This movie is a huge waste of time. reviewText: IN A NUTSHELL:This is a grand but light-hearted spectacle that goes beyond the farthest digital marker and still manages to deliver a story worthy of the epic experimental form.WHAT'S "SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW" ALL ABOUT?:In 2 words -- limitless possibilities. We have a grand story that fully utilizes the enormous scope of this epic digital production. Gwyneth Paltrow and Jude Law interact sensationally with sets that were literally never there. Unfortunately, they get tripped up and bogged down with a lot of mindless, out-of-place banter which gives the impression that there is poor chemistry between the two leads. Nevertheless, a new and exciting digital world has been created by the Conran brothers and they will be back with more for us to behold.This film sets up a very retro yet futuristic atmosphere, very much in the spirit of "Things To Come" which starred Raymond Massey [James Dean's father in East of Eden]. In Sky Captain, however, the universe that Raymond Massey could only hint at in "Things To Come" was actually constructed for us to see through the eyes of Jude Law and Gwyneth Paltrow.Naturally, our heros are fighting against all odds and the ticking clock to save the world. Fortunately, they have all the interesting and amazing gadgets they need to get the job done and amaze us in the process. Just like the sensational serials of the early television age, they offer everything we could want in a visual spectacle: Giant Evil Robots - Mad Scientists - Flying Aircraft Carriers - Fighter Planes that double as submarines - heroines with eyepatches - and some romance thrown in.IF YOU LIKED THIS FILM ALSO CONSIDER SEEING:"The Incredibles", "Mars Attacks", and, from the early days, "Superman: the Animated Series" (1940), "Mechanical Monsters" (1941), Dave Fleischer, "King of the Rocket Men" - Serial (1949), Fred Brannon.ABOUT THE DVD:I have the "Special Collector's Edition" - Widescreen. They also offer this edition in "Full-Screen" format, but you can't get both formats in the same set. Having seen the film in both formats, I can't imagine getting the full-screen edition as it does lessen the awe-inspiring impact and the enormous scope of the digital sets. It also tends to break up some of the scenes as this film was clearly meant to be seen in widescreen format.DVD Features:Available Subtitles: English, Spanish; Available Audio Tracks: English (Dolby Digital 5.1), French (Dolby Digital 2.0 Surround); Commentary by producer Jon Avent plus filmmaker Kerry Conran and the VFX crew; "Brave New World" featurette; "The Art of the World of Tomorrow" featurette; The original 6-minute short; Deleted Scenes and a Gag Reel
summary: EXPERIMENTAL FORMAT DELIVERS THINGS TO COME FOR MOVIE LOVERS

reviewText: 'Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow' is without a doubt one of the coolest movies ever made!  Giant robots, rockets, jet packs, ray guns, mutant animals - Sky Captain's got all this and so much more!  Every frame of this film is a work of art!  The widescreen DVD release is perfect except for three things: 1) Viewers are forced to watch (or skip through) several trailers for movies no one cares about before finally getting to Sky Captain's main menu; 2) The DVD case doesn't come with an insert - what's up with that?! 3) With all that tremendous Kevin Conran artwork lying around, how come the powers that be gave us such a lackluster DVD cover?  5 stars for the movie, 4 and a half for the disc.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" is a masterpiece.  The movie was made with a blue screen, and the backgrounds were added.  They could have chosen to give a totally surreal feel to it as you have with the Batman series or "Dick Tracy", but it fit the setting perfectly.I would call this the 2000 attempt of "Raiders Of The Lost Ark".  There are many similarities between the two pictures, such as the time setting, the homage to 40's serials, the action, having a foreign sidekick, one graphic horrific death scene toward the end, and even having some of the action in Nepal.  This movie also borrowed from other action movies including Jurassic Park.This movie was very well done, but I actually didn't like it.  A movie like that is of course a time waster, but this one made me feel the time was wasted.One drawback is that the target audience seems to be an under thirty viewer who enjoys 40's movies.  This movie captures the 40's films even more effectively than Raiders, and that may be its undoing.  For this person who is more at home in the '70's and '80's, I found this movie in some ways before my time and in other ways after my time.
summary: One Of Those Movies I Objectively Thought Was Fantastic And Subjectively Did Not Like
Title: N/A

reviewText: First off, you CAN skip the previews. Hit the chapter advance button and you'll skip to the next preview. True, you can't hit the menu button, but this is better than some Universal DVDs from a few years back. Still, it's something that has kept this DVD from getting 5 stars.The DVD itself contains your run-of-the-mill features. A 2-chapter featurette that goes over how the director started making a 6-minute short and how he eventually was able to pull together all the elements needed to make this movie that plays homage to a by-gone era. There's also a gag real and deleted scenes section. But, that's about it. Hence, the DVD itself, coupled with the previews, would give this a 2-star rating.But, the movie itself brings the entire package to 4 stars. I myself love special features, but I usually watch them once. What  Kerry Conran has achieved is nothing short of brilliance. Sky Captain, played by Jude Law, must try and save the world from a mad scientist and his giant robots. The story itself takes place somewhere between WWI and WWII.The story has so many plot holes, even Jello would flow through it. There are so many inacuracies in the story, some might start shaking their heads in disbelief. But it all serves a purpose. Sky Captain plays homage to movies of a bygone era. From the sci-fi b-movies of the 50's all the way back to the cliff-hanging serials from earlier on, the wooden acting, the halos around the actors, the fuzzy coloring. It all plays homage to movies from an era that I never got to experience except on TV.The plot holes and inacuracies are dangled out to the audience in complete glory. It's done on purpose. Those movies were NOT there to send a statement or make you think. They were made for escapism at it's purest form. Sky Captain is all that and more.For those that just want to escape, this is a movie to add to your collection. It's worth watching over and over again.
summary: Excellent movie - you CAN skip the previews as well

reviewText: Someone called this eye candy. Are they blind? Consistently bad photography and poor lighting do not constitute eye candy. If you actually want to be able to SEE any of the stars in this movie you will need to watch them in a different movie. The dreary visuals of this movie will drag you down sooner or later. By the way, I enjoyed the brown tinting in "O Brother, Where Art Thou?" which was masterfully done, so I'm not simply someone who dislikes any attempt to manipulate color or film. But in this movie, the attempt was poorly done and failed miserably.As for the plot, I'm not the best one to evaluate it. It was so slow and so boring and so unfocused that I lost interest quickly. I couldn't make it to the end of the movie.The characters? I don't know them as people and thus I don't care. And I always had the feeling that the actors were not sure about what they were doing or were not committed to the movie.Once of the worst movies I've tried to watch in a very long time.

reviewText: Let me start off by saying that "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" is not a movie for everyone. If you're looking for a tightly knit story with intriguing plot twists, or deep and interesting character studies, you won't find those in here. But what if I told you that the film falls short on those elements on purpose, because director Kerry Conran's vision is a highly stylized film that devotes itself to the aesthetics, and makes everything else secondary.The plot is intentionally filled with clichés of vintage cinema. We begin by the mysterious disappearances of scientists, with a city newspaper reporter (Gweneth Paltrow) chasing the story. Soon giant robots are marching through the streets of New York. And who does the world call to its salvation?---A lone pilot in a WWII-style fighter jet named Sky Captain (Jude Law). The pilot and the reporter, who happens to be ex-lovers, soon pair up to unravel the evil plans of a mad scientist, whom we eventually learn is in the process of deploying something called the "doomsday device".The art direction of this film recalls aesthetics of an era that is long past. Being my age it's not easy for me to relate to a lot of the artistic references being made to a world reminiscent of the 40's and 50's. But being somewhat appreciative of older things, I can say everything in the film invokes imageries of a "film noir", and the artistic composition of a WWII propaganda poster. The fact that this is a movie about a vintage world made mostly with CGI is a clever joke that Conran seems to enjoy playing on his audience throughout the movie. He amuses himself with plenty of tongue-in-cheek references, such as a screening of "Wizard of OZ" at the beginning of the movie, foreshadowing a later scene where the characters encounter an ominous hologram projection of the villain in front of the gate to his lair.Despite the characters being mere supporting acts in this movie, I thought the cast does bring a nice touch in a story that is otherwise a tribute to symbolisms of an older era. First of all it must be awkward to act in environments that are pretty much added on later but are nearly non-existent at the time of filming, but they manage to make it look convincing. Jude Law as Sky Captain and Gweneth Paltrow as Polly Perkins have good on-screen chemistry. Their romantic tug-of-war and playful bickering are welcome distractions when the film's nostalgic imageries become a bit repetitive at times. Angelina Jolie as Frankie Cook, commander of the British Air Force, has a very pretentious accent, but looks ravishing in a Nazi-like tight-fitted pilot uniform, with an eye patch no less.A film like "Sky Captain" succeeds in what it does because it makes no pretense that it's purely about the aesthetics here, and to that end it's a marvel in its execution. Everything's done in meticulous detail. The pace of the film is very fast and tight, so tight that it seems at times almost unsentimental. It's also a film that's so unique it seems almost out of its time and place. And for that, I applaud it.

reviewText: Sky Captain was a treat to watch for me.  I am a huge movie buff and am often very critical of films because quite frankly I have annoyingly strict tastes.  Sci Fi is a difficult genre for me because of the "cheese" factor.  You find this in blockbusters like Chronicles of Riddick or other mid range sci fi flicks.  You know the ones I am talking about.  Decent budget films with heavy special effects, maybe one known cardboard actor and an unknown female willing to bare skin.  Sky Captain luckily avoided these stereotypes by creating a unique, comic book like world and a rock solid cast.The exact story line is pretty much a tried and true Bond (007) like story of a maniacle mastermind hellbent on ridding the world of all social ills by "cleansing" or destroying it.  Here we have the out of touch scientist playing Noah as he scrambles to re-start society as God had in Genesis of the Old Testament.  To carry out the plot line the story is nicely done and not too difficult for the average viewer to follow but intricate enough to keep hardcores happy.  The downside to the plot for me was that the producers really did not have the time in a major motion picture to develope the story more efficiently.  In other words to keep the film rolling and exciting you (the viewer) may feel you are being wisked through the story on a rollercoaster as events happen extremely fast and often with very little to no explanation.  Also the story is interupted by numerous and sometimes baffling or unnecesarry action sequences.The quality of the production however was extremely good.  The use of Blue screen filming for an all CGI background film was not cheesy or campy as some might expect.  In fact it creates a unique atmosphere to this fantasy setting.  I especially like the 1920's atmosphere with a futuristic twinge.The casting was well researched with most characters adequately placed and performed nicely.  The only exception I would gripe with is that of the female lead or Gweneth Paltrow.  Usually a fine actress heralded for past performances she seemed too rigid and out of place in this film.  Many of her lines were delivered with such a lack of emotion she seemed to be a robot.  Quite ironic since the film is full of robots but sadly they seem to have more personality than Paltrow could give her character.  She obviously was cast for her name and star power and the role probably would have been better suited for someone with a bit more flair as one would stereotype in a comic book journalist.  Beyond that gripe the cast performed very well.Overall Sky Captain was simply a fun film to watch.  Die hard sci fi and Anime fans will enjoy the film as a basic action filled adventure but will probably want more from the story.  Overall I think had this film been a trilogy or a TV mini series it would have been more free to explore the story and develope the plot lines more adequately.

reviewText: The director of this movie apparently wanted to create something that reminded us about the old Science Fiction theater days. If you tend to like the direction science fiction is headed and don't want to look back, skip this movie.I fit the in the last category and wish I hadn't wasted money on this rental or the time invested to sit through it all.
