reviewText: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow is a very enjoyable sci-fi adventure movie.  Set in 1939 New York, the basic plot revolves around the mysterious disappearance of a group of scientists that coincide with giant robot attacks on major cities across the world.  The prime suspect in these events is a Dr. Totenkopf (German for death's head and symbolized by a skull and crossbones).  Trying to get to the bottom of the plot is Joseph "Sky Captain" Sullivan (Jude Law) and reporter Polly Perkins (Gwenyth Paltrow).  Their journey takes them around the globe as they unravel mystery piece by piece until Totenkopf's plot reaches its climax at the end of the movie.  Along the way, they are assisted by Sky Captain's weapons specialist, Dax (Giovanni Ribisi) and Captain Francesca "Franky" Cook (Angelina Jolie).The plot movies along at a good pace after the opening sequence.  Law and Paltrow have good chemistry, but one would expect that as they have worked together previously.  Their banter back and forth is reminiscent of that of Harrison Ford and Carrie Fischer in the Star Wars movies.  Paltrow's Polly also has some Lois Lane qualities as she never forgets that she is after the story.  She also plays the Jimmy Olsen part as photographer, and she has trouble keeping up with her camera and film.  Law's Sky Captain comes off as the typical rogue hero character.  He is a vigilante in the vain of Batman; however, he is called by a special radio signal rather than the visual "bat signal".The visual effects of Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow are likely to be polarizing.  The film was shot entirely on blue screen sets with all of the background filled in by digital artists and finished with an antique style.  It gives the movie somewhat of a whimsical tone and sets it apart as not of this world.  Viewers can gain a larger appreciation of how the film was put together through the special features "Brave New World I" and "Brave New World II".  These also give the story of how the movie came to be, and it seems writer/director Kerry Conran's 15 minutes of fame as the movie did not cover its budget.  However, the finances should not diminish what they accomplished.Overall, the movie is very enjoyable.  It is one that boys/men of all ages will like.  The special features are interesting and enrich the viewer's appreciation of the film that they have seen.Overall:  B+
summary: Fun And Adventure For Sci-Fi Fans

reviewText: Someone does something INNOVATIVE in movies! Just imagine...those great Alex Raymond-drawn Flash Gordon strips of the forties and thirties come to life in full art deco regalia, aesthetics absolutely perfectly replicated in 3 dimensions, with the perfect casting of Gwyneth Paltrow as a Lois Lane-type reporter, Giovannia Ribisi as Mr. Gadgets and Mr. Matinee Idol himself, Jude Law, as the hero, and you have "Sky Captain & The World of Tomorrow"...a film I KNEW was going to be groundbreaking when it was in the promo stage.This is the kind of movie that is a perfect marriage of major league visuals and suitable acting, and, "Gladiator" aside, is the one film that makes PERFECT use of CGI technology! The entire film was done against a bluescreen, with very few real-world props! There have been other reviews of this film decrying the wooden acting of those involved, but you have to remember that 1) Acting WITH real-world references isn't easy, and 2) These actors were doing their thing WITHOUT real-world references, something I've always appreciated about a good sci-fi or fantasy movie...The story concerns the classic megalomaniacal villain scenario of a mad, but brilliant scientist who has misused his gift to satisfy his own outsized paranoia. Laurence Olivier is digitally resurrected to play the computer generated persona of this man, a Dr. "Totenkopf", (done VERY "Wizard of Oz",) who has gone about sending his mechanical minions to sap energy from large cities whilst destroying same to build an ark that will preserve life and humanity offworld as the Earth descends into mayhem that he is at least partially responsible for.To say that the visuals are mind-boggling would be an understatement....the visuals are easily the equal of any of the earlier "Star Wars" films and the last fifteen minutes of the film are worth the price of admission. Jude Law is a capable hero as Sky Captain Joe Sullivan, but it's Gwyneth Paltrow as Polly Perkins, a blonde xeroxing of good old Lois Lane, that steals the movie from him! She makes all the mistakes a normal person would make in the movie...inadvertently giving away their presence when they try to stealthily sabotage Totenkopf's lair; not having enough film to capture some of the most incredible, newsworthy tableau a journalist has ever laid eyes on, and doing some of the worst backseat driving since Lucille Ball! The banter between her and Sullivan is straight out of a Bogart and Bacall movie.Some of the actors in the film that portray the scientists that Totenkopf is either killing off or forcing to work for him from the grave, (he managed to infuse his persona in his vast array of computer and broadcasting circuits at his lair,) are truly convincing as meek, put-upon scientists running for their lives from a supposedly dead madman. However, they seem to be very self-involved about it, not really caring that the world at large is in danger as well.Complex and entertaining, "Sky Captain" was perhaps the most underrated film of 2004, and the only one I saw fit to see in the theater. You better believe I had to have it on DVD....!The ending is very cute, btw.By all means, GET IT!

reviewText: This movie reminds me of a Disney film long ago, about Dave Stevens character, "The Rocketeer."  If Disney had CGI at the time, the movie would have been a success.  This one is in the spirit of the old time movie serials and while the action wasn't over the top in many places it was a very good movie. I did like the fact that, as one of the reviewers put it, there was no modern profanity and nudity.  It'd be out of place in this perfect movie about a retro future that looks like it came straight out of the 1940's art deco era.  I wonder if Dave Stevens is promoting a new version of his character after watching this?
summary: Everything the Rocketeer should have been!

reviewText: Despite the impressive special effects this film seems almost to determined to do more and comes up with less.  The plot line is fairly uncomplicated the actors seem trapped in a lack luster play with bad scripts and bad jokes.  I couldn't help feeling that I was watching a combination of James Bond movies set in a 1930's sci-fi serial.  Far too many plot lines were left hanging and unexplained. In general this film is fun to watch for all of the hints to classic movies from the 1930's and even up to the laser duel from recent Star Wars movies.  Overall this could have been a real classic had more attention to plot, acting and scripting been applied.  As it is, it comes out as a low "B" class movie with high budget effects but no real substance, a pity as it could have been really something.

reviewText: If you love comic books of the 1930s and movies from the "Film Noir"-era then Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow is a must see for you. It is like comic book characters fly off the page at you. It is much like the Flash Gordon flicks of long ago with some snazzy not so special-special effects. What little plot there is comes largely plagiarized out of 1930's science fiction scripts. If you believe that comic books are in-depth reading for you, then the plot and dialogue will be just fine. No matter how much glitter you put on scat...it is still scat. 90+ minutes of my life down the drain.

reviewText: Jude Law and Gwyneth Paltrow are paired as a pilot and a journalist in conquest to save the world from the mad scientist.  This scientist has created robots who are overtaking New York.  There is a mysterious assassin trying to kill off all the remaining scientists who can prevent the apocalipse.Part adventure, part romance, part nostalgic movie set in art deco style, this film has feel and touch of the old era.  Although at one point there is a clip of the movie "Wizard of Oz" which must have been filmed more that 30 years ago.  That confused me a little bit.  If it was supposed to be a metaphor for Paltrow's character in this movie, I have not quite got the message.This movie is cute and unpretentious but easy to let go of once you've seen it.
summary: Sci-fi fantasy in art deco style
Title: N/A

reviewText: Over two decades ago, the Disney film "Tron" with its computer-generated images was supposed to revolutionize filmmaking.  Coupled with a rather weak script and wooden direction, the film didn't accomplish its goal at the time, only recently acquiring "cult" status.2004's "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" was supposed to do the same thing, and may have accomplished that feat in a mild way, showing that a movie could be created with actors responding to direction while acting on a blue screen set.  Unfortunately, there lies the film's biggest weakness.  The actors seem unsure as to what they are reacting and it shows.  Like such effects-laden predecessors as "Godzilla" and "Spawn," the performers' reactions are either too slow or quirky, revealing the actors' doubts about how they should respond to the director's on-screen intent.Combining cutting-edge computer effects, comic book-like espionage, elements of film noir (in sepia tones, no less), globetrotting daring do, and 1930's set pieces, the film is too over-the-top to be believed.  The producers may have thought they were paying homage to early films but I feel that they borrowed a bit too heavily from the older, and much better, films.Check out the sound effects of The Iron Giant-like robots' laser beams, identical to those produced by the Martian spacecraft in George Pal's "War of the Worlds".  The battles over the skies of Manhattan look like they were lifted from any installment of Max Fleischer's "Superman" shorts of the 1940's.  Didn't Roger Moore have a car that turned into a submarine in 1977's "The Spy Who Loved Me"?  It might not be a car, but Law's plane does a remarkably similar feat.And how many times since 1937's real-life Hindenburg disaster can one see a dirigible explode???Besides the obvious "salutes" to "Metropolis" and "The Wizard of Oz," the film also lifts from "Mars Attacks" and "Jurassic Park".As for the cast, Jude Law is a bit too small in stature and refined to be the "rugged hero" and "savior of the world".  Gwyneth Paltrow tries her best to be "the girl Friday" but she's saddled with lines that are so awful that her drama teacher must be wincing.  She, at least, gets to sing "Over the Rainbow" in the closing credits, and affords herself adequately.  Jolie, sporting a sexy eye patch and form-fitting outfit, gets to make what amounts to an extended cameo.  Her English accent isn't too bad, though.And the credits do state that the estate of Sir Laurence Olivier did approve of his image and voice being used in the film.  Well, I know "Larry" is grimacing in his grave.When I saw the theatrical trailer for the film prior to its release, I wondered what were Law, Paltrow, and Jolie doing in a sci-fi epic.Now that I have viewed the entire film, I'm still wondering.I wonder do they still have the same agent, respectively.
summary: All CGI's are not created equal!

reviewText: The first time I watched this movie I thought it had the potential to be one of the great all-time sci-fi movies. Of course the story line was interesting but the hook was the time period - 1940's - and so the lure of art-deco production values. It's the kind of film that was 'good' on the old CRT as a rental but blooms into a Blu-Ray 'very good' movie on a 50" HD plasma . I call this the 'HD-GEE!' effect- hence the title of this review ( ahem ).Look, either you like this type of movie or you don't. The actors are two-dimensional like comic-book actors would be, the story is outrageous, the pretensions are ever present, the star doesn't get the girl, the bad guy is snuffed by father time, the rules of time and space and speed and mass are broken all over the place but that's okay- THE BLU-RAY IMAGE IS GREAT ON MY BIG HDTV!!!Does anything else really matter???

reviewText: This film looks so beautiful.  I just wish that I liked it more.  Done almost entirely with blue screen, the actors really had their job cut out for them imagining all of the crazy things going on around them.  If you have ever seen the old seriels of Flash Gordon, this is very much the style of the movie.  Set in 1939, with strange future gadgets that seem a little silly now.  Sort of like when you watch the old Star Trek series with the ship being operated by a lot of knobs and dials when we know now that it won't be that way whenever we acheive that ability.  While Sky Captain is ambitious, it just falls flat for me and didn't rouse me into really caring for the characters and story.  This one is worth renting once to see the beautiful effects.  I would wait to purchase until after you have given it a watch.

Mind Bending!  That's really all you need in sci-fi action.

reviewText: My wife and I totally agree with Roger Ebert's review of this movie. It is fun, imaginative and creative. It has a nostalgic quality to it for those who grew up after WW II and who dwelled on the "possibilities" of the "'World of Tomorrow'" whether we garnered them from books, television or even the radio.We were impressed with the acting of the major performers: Jude Law: Sky Captain, Gwyneth Paltrow: Polly Perkins, Angelina Jolie: Franky and Giovanni Ribisi: Dex Dearborn. The plot is the classic struggle between good and evil. The above are "good guys"; the bad are the mainfestations of as well as the "evil" Dr. Totenkopf.The cinematography really used special effects to give some of  the screen sequences a "comic book"-like appearance as well as a long-ago-and-far-away motif.The imaginative props which appear throughout the entire film fit the plot appropriately.My wife and I would recommend it to anyone who has a vivid imagination and enjoys such creative "story telling" as this film enbodies.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film takes place in the same world as the adventure serials of the thirties that inspired George Lucas and Steven Spielberg. It even has the same feel as "Star Wars" or "Indiana Jones" but nowhere near as good.  Huge robots are firing on New York City as they attempt to unearth the generators from below ground.  Six scientists have been kidnapped and a seventh is fearful he may be next.  Before he gets picked up he contacts reporter Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow) to tell her who he thinks is behind it and why. He thinks the man may be a missing scientist named Totenkopf. Totenkopf hasn't been seen or heard from since the war. Before he went missing he was rumored to be working on some kind of doomsday machine that would bring about the end of the world. Providing the terrified citizens protection from the air is Sky Captain a.k.a. Joe (Jude Law). Polly and Joe were once an item but the two broke up due to suspicious minds and sabotage.on  The old flames team up to track down Totenkopf and stop him before he destroys the world. Angelina Jolie (looking very sexy in an eye patch and tight leather and speaking in a British accent) plays Frankie Cook. Frankie runs a refueling station in the clouds. She is also a Commander in the British Air Force. Polly suspects Joe of cheating on her with Franky which leads to some friction when the two call on Frankie for help. Jolie's screen time is limited to just three scenes.  The rest of the film is carried by Law and Paltrow and it doesn't always work. Paltrow, though very attractive, is extremely grating as Polly. She is constantly screaming and shouting at Joe and the two lovers can never get along. Jude is no Harrison Ford and doesn't make for a very thrilling hero. The villains are more interesting  and that isn't saying much. Bai Ling is a robotic assassin who channels other films of the era by not talking. Totenkopf is "played" by Laurence Olivier. The director used old outtakes of the legend to create two scenes, played out in a hologram, that barely last three minutes. Interesting concept but it doesn't pay off. The reason to see the film is it's amazing visual scheme. It's fun and exciting for a little while but it all builds to a boring confrontation and  ends on a terrible joke.

reviewText: I guess the main appeal of this movie is the way it is filmed. It has that old 60s classic look and feel. Like those old TV series with the tin foil robots. I suppose that's meant for nostalgic effect but probably not a compelling reason to go see a movie. I mean, if you have color, USE color! In the end, it just made me feel kind of dizzy.The CGI graphics are 2nd rate and the story is not very interesting. Maybe it would've been better if we got to see a Totenkopf. This movie is pretty short so not great value for your money although I'm not sure it would've been a good thing to make it any longer. Escepecially when I'm not particularly a fan of Jude Law nor Gwyneth Paltrow.Having said that, the movie does have its moments and I do like Angelina Jolie, although I'm not sure why you would cover half her face with an eyepatch. Overall, still an okay movie to watch.

reviewText: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow is one movie that embodies 'fun' in a manner I have never before seeen in a movie. Set in 1939, this film is an excellent snapshot of the era's sci-fi, taken with a camera from the 21st Century. With giant, riveted robots and automated planes wreaking havoc on New York City(mysteriously stealing the city's generators)and around the world, Sky Captain (Jude Law) is called to the rescue. Ta-da! With his highly modified P-40 fighter-plane, Sky Captain brings down several of the metallic brutes, when they suddenly take to the skies and leave. He and Polly Perkins (a reporter for 'The Chronicle') take off in search of answers, leading them on a quest across the world, and into realms beyond belief.This movie does not pretend to be realistic. It does not intend to be emotionally charged. Nobody was gunning for the Oscars. But what it meant to do was be a fun, eye-catching, exciting adventure for the whole family----something it does with both barrels (and ray-guns) blazing. It is unique, captivating, and well-made. With all the graphic violence and immoral behavior splayed across the silver screen so much, it is nice to see a change.Ryan RobledoAuthor of the Aelnathan:

reviewText: An anonymous note brings Polly Perkins, ace woman reporter, to Radio City Music Hall to watch "Wizard of Oz."  An elderly gentlemen comes to her and tells her that he has information on the scientists who are disappearing.  Before his precipitous departure he tells her he's the next scientist to disappear and when she asks who's doing this, the one-word reply is Totemkopf.Next thing you know, a machine driven blitzkrieg hits NYC.  Mercenary "SSky Captain" (Jude Law) is flying over the city doing his best to kill the invading enemy machines.Perkins and Joe team up to solve both of the cases.  There's a lot of romentic and comedic tension between the two.  They used to be an 'item' til she caught him cheating on her and messed with his plane's fuel line.The effects are stunning.  The pellucid colors remind me of a vintage comic--or an old photo colored with Marshal oils.  The scenery is pretty amazing and the action good enough to keep you riveted in your seat for most of the show.True, the performance is not up to the actor's standard, but this is not a drama.The running plot about Paltrow and her camera was one of the funniest bits in the movie.  I can so relate to her problems with taking pictures.Overall, a very worthwhile film to own and watch again.

reviewText: While I didn't buy it here, I do own the blu-ray version of this film. I am in my late 50's and was an early fan of scifi pulp fiction and the golden age of comics and enjoy old 1950s scifi TV series such as Flash Gordon. If that applies to you as well then this film is a definite must have for your film collection!I love this film and it is one of my all-time personal favorites. Sky Captain is entertaining, highly imaginative and a very unique PG rated "popcorn" film unlike almost anything Hollywood has done before or since. The story takes place in an alternative 1939 world both familiar and very different at the same time. I won't discuss the story line here, as I don't want to spoil the surprises for you.Profanity level: Very MildSex: NoneGore: NoneViolence: MildA good family film: YesWarning: If you were really into scifi pulp fiction and/or the golden age of comics expect to have you jaw hit the ground after the first few minutes of viewing this film!
summary: For those who love the golden age of comics and scifi pulp fiction

reviewText: It is unfortunate that such a movie with so much potential(see the six minute short included on the disc that was the genesis the director touted around Hollywood to get the thing made) had so little to offer when all was said and done.The movie has a quite sumputous sepia toned look throughout,art deco buildings and even a late 30s P-40 Curtis Warhawk fighter plane complete with sharks teeth on the nose(the captains' preferred mode of transport).However long on LOOK this movie is does NOT compensate for the stilted and see through plot that runs through this movie like so much water through a sieve.The science fiction pulp mags and 30s/40s serials that obviously inspired this movie had more depth and originality to them than this very shallow and cheap imitation.Jude Law as the titular sky captain does as good a job as he can considering the material he has to work with and Gynneth Paltrow shows us once again why she is one of the top most wooden actresses in Hollywood today.All in all this is one BIG disappointment;nice to look at but nothing under the hood.
summary: Sky Captain barely makes it off the ground.

reviewerName: Robert S. Gartner "I am the Grungeman"
reviewText: What viewers have to understand about this movie is that it pays homage to all those movie serials of the '30's and '40's and television serials of the '50's. Is it as good as Spielberg's 'Raiders' series? It is the same and different: like 'Raiders of the Lost Ark,' it is a loving tribute to the early days of filmmaking with more special effects. It is reminiscent of actor Buster Crabbe and the serials 'Buck Rogers' and 'Captain Video.' Like those series, this movie succeeds in capturing the early science fiction view of killer robots and mad scientists. Jude Law and Gwyenth Paltrow are very likable as the lead characters trying to save the world from the evil Dr. Totenkopf. Angelina Jolie and her beautiful lips, however, only make what amounts to a cameo appearance. The basic fact of this movie is this: if you enjoy nostalgia and old movies ('Metropolis', 'Things To Come', etc.), I believe you will enjoy this film immensely. If, on the other hand, your tastes run to more modern films which star the Special Effects people ('Terminator', 'The Matrix', etc.) rather than the actors, or, films rooted in the 'now,' you will be disappointed by this film. I urge you to watch this movie with an open mind and then go out and discover the early days of cinema.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Back in 1996, wannabe filmmaker Kerry Conran was holed up in his small Sherman Oaks apartment hunched over his Apple computer incessantly rendering segments and scenes for a trailer of an epic movie that only existed in his head.  Two years later he had an art deco tinged, vintage-looking six minute black and white teaser that would become SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW (Paramount).A screenplay was begun after producer John Avnet saw that short film in 1998 and committed to making Kevin's big screen vision a reality.  Two years later, shooting began in London with Kevin directing. Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow and Angelina Jolie acted out every digitally storyboarded scene on a bare, blue stage.  All the globe trotting locations and huge aerial and underwater action set pieces were then computer designed with the actors seamlessly inserted.I mention these things because the art of this film is at least as important as the story. Set in the late 1930s, giant robots invade New York City and perky reporter Paltrow alerts old lover Joe "Sky Captain" Sullivan (Jude Law).  Their daunting task is to figure out who's behind this attack and stop a conspiracy to destroy civilization in order to save the planet.  An idea that resonates on some level today.The exquisitely beautiful, period perfect, richly detailed results didn't connect to the full audience potential this breathtaking breakthrough film deserves.Extras include three informative featurettes on the art and making of this film and there are two superb commentaries.  One from the filmmakers and a lone producer commentary from Avnet that should be the model for all future producer commentaries.This DVD is highly recommended.Maybe there will be a two disc extended edition that includes the finished version of the important deleted scenes and a separate disc that actualy shows the digital artists at work creating the astonishingly detailed, beautifully executed visuals that look straight out of the 30s.

reviewText: **1/2Watching Kerry Conran`s "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" is like seeing one of those beautifully illustrated sc-fi adventure comic books from the 1930's miraculously brought to life.  Unfortunately, that turns out to be something of a mixed blessing, since the film captures some of the weaknesses as well as many of the strengths of that particular genre.This is the first movie ever made in which the actors were filmed entirely in front of a blue screen, so that nothing we see, except for the performers, actually exists in our three-dimensional world.  In terms of its visual design, the movie is a gorgeous combination of art deco architecture and sepia-toned cinematography.  Whether it's a bird's-eye view of the Manhattan skyline or a bi-plane soaring majestically through the clouds, the effect is eye-popping and dazzling to say the least.However, once the novelty of the look wears off - and that happens about 15 minutes into the movie - we're left with the storyline and characters, neither of which come close to matching the beauty of the visuals.  The plot, about a mad scientist who sends out killer giant robots to facilitate his plan for destroying the world, comes across as an odd sort of precursor to Spielberg's later "War of the Worlds," with bits of "Lost Horizon," "King Kong," and other early twentieth century movie classics thrown in for good measure.  The characters are mere cardboard cutouts - appropriate given the nature of the enterprise, perhaps, but not very compelling for the audience watching them.  Thus, while the movie LOOKS like a comic book, it also, unfortunately, PLAYS like one, giving us little to hang on to in the way of human interest or human emotion.Jude Law plays Sky Captain Joe Sullivan, a crack pilot determined to bring an end to this Teutonic reign of terror, and Gwyneth Paltrow is Polly Perkins, a newspaper photographer and occasional love interest, who goes along for the ride.  Law and Paltrow deliver stiff, arch performances, partly because that's what the style calls for, and partly, no doubt, because it must be awfully tough for an actor to develop a meaningful performance with nothing but a blue screen to interact with.  I guess that, with this film, it's finally official; after years of Hollywood edging us in that direction, the actor has become little more than just another special effect after all."Sky Captain" is an awfully nice try at something new and innovative, but it's a little too old-hat - apart from its visuals, that is - to be truly groundbreaking.

reviewText: For Saturday matinee movie pleasure this film would be hard to beat.  Think "Buck Rogers" meets "Indiana Jones" with a healthy dollop of "The Wizard of Oz" thrown in.  A plot by an evil genius has unleashed robots of every description, including ones that flap their metal wings like birds, upon the world's resources.  Sky Captain Joseph Sullivan (played by Jude Law) tries to stop the invasions to no avail, with troublesome Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow) tagging along.  Surmounting various trials and tribulations along the way the duo manages to reach the locus of this menace to the earth.All the 1930s film types and colors are here: sepia tones and the almost cartoonish skyscrapers, but with 70 year old technology mated to fantastically advanced machines on both sides of the conflict.  "Wild Wild West" comes to mind here with its anachronistic blend of high-tech and antique inventions.  Other stereotypes are blended in too--surely the reporter's name "Polly Perkins" draws on Sweet Polly (the reporter) in the Underdog cartoon series.You must suspend most of your logical faculties to best enjoy this show.  Consider the absurdity of an industrial center big and sophisticated enough to create these huge flying robots (not to mention the other machines) just to steal generators.  It'd be like sending an Abrams tank to grab a few tin cans.  Or the side by side high and low technologies of prop aircraft that can do so much more than just fly.  But it's all good fun to watch anyway.One slightly jarring error in the movie is the reference to the Great War as WWI.  Of course it didn't take on that name until after WWII, which is yet to happen.This isn't a great movie, but it is an entertaining one.  Sit back and let the thrills and chills wash over you.  You may not like the slightly hazy look of the film (which is deliberate) but you've got to admire the computer graphics anyway.  The rating is a rather clean PG, probably because of one strong scene in which someone gets thoroughly electrocuted.  The show was not a big hit so don't wait for a sequel to enjoy a little Saturday afternoon magic.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In "Sky Captain", Joe (Jude Law" fights to save the world from a mysterious onslaught of hulking, flying and blasting machines bent on...some diabolical mission.  Along with a nosy newspaper reporter (Paltrow) and with some help from the one-eyed commander of a brigade of British fliers, Joe tracks the machines across the world.  Joe's weapon of choice: a P-40 Hawk tricked out with all sorts of James Bond type gearJoe links the machines with a mysterious scientist named Tottenkopf, and a mysterious plan called "The World of Tomorrow".  Can Joe solve the mystery before...well before it's too late?This was an immensely disappointing movie.  Virtually everything in "Sky Captain" is borrowed from somewhere else - from the "Indiana Jones" movies to the Fleischer "Superman" animated shorts of the 1930s; from "Flash Gordon" to "Jurassic Park", from "The Wizard of Oz" to "Far Horizons" - so that you spend less time enjoying the movie, and more time combating a stiff case of deja-vu.  When it isn't regaling you with its grasp of other films, TV shows or comic books, "Sky Captain" tosses you generic CGI combat scenes - like those between Joe and a squadron of flying robots through midtown Manhattan, or Angelina Jolie and her squadron up against the robots below the waves of the Pacific.  Rather than transitioning from one scene to the next, "Sky Captain" just jumps into different famous movies - even the identity of the mysterious Tottenkpf is a form of homage.  The special effects aren't all that special - though the CGI seamlessly blends live-action with computer animation, the overall effect breathes less life into the animated parts than simply turn it all into a big cartoon.
summary: Unentertaining Pastiche of a lost age

reviewText: In a gorgeous 1948 [?] of RADAR, dirigibles, disembarcations at the Empire State Building -- all in the 1st 10 minutes! -- the hero to call in emergencies is the heroic Sky Captain.  Jude Law is the handsome hero who inhabits these lovely CGI landscapes, & he fits in amazingly well.  Killer robots, a secret base, and an exotic flying aircraft carrier made/manned by the UK, -Sky Capt- also features a plucky asistant Dex [Giovanni Ribisi] , a villainous Lawrence Olivier in a powerful if posthumous role, Sir Michael Gambon as Mr. Paley, the reporter's boss, & the heroic Frankie Cook [played by Angelina Jolie] who commands the above-mentioned UK carrier.Portraying lovers even more cursed than King Kong & Ann Darrow, Gweneth Paltrow & Jude Law shine in what had to be difficult roles; most of this movie existed only in  a computer.  Green-screen acting is a revolutionary experience for both actor & CGI artist, & the stars carry out their parts swimmingly.  Altho Paltrow can be irritating as a reporter, who does everything wrong [hey, i was a reporter & i never did any of that stuff!] & who screams a lot, as well.  But she hits her marks & says her lines so convincingly that i was irritated at *her* rather than 'her character'.  Throw in some charming toss-aways: a Professor's lab address is 1138, Godzilla shows up in a Tokyo newspaper, & both the -Venture- [the ship from -King Kong-] & the -Titanic- make sneak cameos -- & you've got a film that enchants as it sweeps you into a Universe that never existed.We went to see this w/a friend from Scotland who sighed afterwards, "Cheese.  But the very best Ermanthaler cheese!"  A good description; it is cheesy.  But, hey, i'd live there in a heartsbeat!
summary: Beautiful View of a World That Wasn't -- & Shoulda Been

reviewText: "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" was Kerry Conran's one-man homage (the original six-minute short, included as an extra, was made on a Mac in his apartment, no less) to the sci-fi film serials of the 1930s and 40s, replete with snappy, sultry reporter Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow) in search of the ultimate scoop, cocky fighter pilot Joe Sullivan (Jude Law), the over-eager, clean-cut techno-whiz kid sidekick Dex (Giovanni Ribisi), and feisty, no-nonsense ex-flame Frankie (Angelina Jolie), commander of an airborne British squadron. I thought the actors did a wonderful job, especially when you consider that there were no sets, props, etc. to set the stage, so to speak.The film was completely created via CGI, and takes viewers from the Art Deco lines of New York to the gardens of Shangri-la on a quest to discover why giant robots are attacking cities around the globe. This is a film of unprecedented beauty, filled to the brim with every child's thrills: dinosaurs, robots, ray guns, dirigibles, rockets, airborne battles, and more, with a dash of romance and intrigue for the grownups. It's even more amazing watching the two-part documentary Brave New World, in which we see the soundstages and blue screens, completely devoid of props, etc. except for the actors and their marks. The costumes, music, and filmmaking lovingly recall the 1930s and 1940s, from the film titles to the sweeping orchestral themes. An experience not to be missed for fans of vintage sci-fi the gloriously cheesy sci-fi serials of decades past.
summary: A stunning, visionary debut that evokes the glory years of the serials

reviewText: I have no idea how a movie with such a large budget like "Sky Captain" gets the green light to go forward.  The movie takes you on a whirl-wind trip from New York to Nepal to a hidden island in the Atlantic with the purpose of saving the world from a mad scientist.  Setting aside the fact that this is a tired plot, there is no convincing motivation for the scientist's actions.  Supposedly he is building a space ship to function as a Noah's Ark in order to start a new world, but he is going to blow up the Earth just for spite?  The movie does capture that 1930's Buck Rogers feel quite well-perhaps a bit too well with bad acting and cheesy special effects brought along as well.  Jude Law is poorly cast as the lead hero.  He is completely unconvincing as an action star. Of course, his character bumbles through the movie and needs saving several times.  I've never seen a lead action hero accomplish so little in a story.  Gwenneth Paltrow plays an annoying career-driven reporter and her acting is surprisingly bad.  Angelina Jolie is competent is a very minor role.  Not only was I disappointed with this movie, but also bored as well despite all the action.  This one is not even worth renting.

reviewText: I eagerly anticipated Kerry Conran's "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow," ever since I saw the previews in the theater.  Who wouldn't love a rollicking yarn set in the glorious adventure hey-days of pre-WWII?  With intrepid heroes with intrepid names like Joseph "Sky Captain" Sullivan (Jude Law) and Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow) engaging in derring-do against a dastardly villain and his titanic robotic minions, what could possibly go wrong?Suffice it to say that for the first ten minutes of "Sky Captain" I was enchanted.  A glorious scene where the Hindenburg III flies through a snow-storm to dock atop the Empire State Building, with various and sundry characters looking gravely concerned and on the verge of panic sets the stage for both grandeur and a suitably sinister plot.What a let-down!  The movie quickly devolves into a murky plot involving some kind of invasion and some kind of plot involving super-secret scientists.  And the performances by this normally-stellar cast are uniformly wooden (with Angelina Jolie the lone exception as the delectable, one-eyed Commander Franky Cook) -- it's almost like George Lucas was in charge.  For actors such as Law, Paltrow, and Giovanni Ribisi to have so many flat, empty scenes is just shocking.  This is a movie where gigantic robots invade New York City, for Pete's sake, and yet in most scenes the actors deliver lines in sotto voce, a soft deadpan that is completely at odds with what is happening around them.  Why bring in the radiant Jude Law and make him act like a young John Gielgud?The plot of "Sky Captain" also has a lumpy, amorphous feeling to it.  Despite a wonderful set-up, we are denied much of an explanation of what is going on, and the "unique condition" of the villain denies us any climactic confrontations between good and evil.  For a movie that deals in such broad characterizations, this is a surprising twist that doesn't work.  Also, the villain has one interesting henchman - an acrobatic female assassin -- who ultimately fails to deliver on her awesomely diabolical potential.  She is no Darth Maul!All in all, Kerry Conran and team have made a landmark film with "Sky Captain," but only on the technical side.  The movie is easily one of the best-looking films I've ever seen, and there are several scenes of considerable imagination and craft.  And yet Conran's bunch was unsuccessful in uniting their amazing vision with the human craft of acting.  The movie feels disjointed, and you can almost picture the actors performing in front of a blue-screen against imaginary backdrops that will be added in later by CGI.  Disbelief cannot be suspended, and as a result, the movie fails.Worth a rental, "Sky Captain" is not essential for any movie library except for its technical expertise.  Here's hoping that Conran and team get another shot at using their amazing technology to tell a great story.
summary: Astounding Visuals Elevate Hum-Drum Story and Acting

reviewText: Okay, so first off I didn't know it was 99% CGI going in.  That might have colored my impressions some.  I liked the movie.  It definitely evoked an older feel, although I was often more reminded of Noir than adventure serials - it sort of bounced between the two, especially in the opening moments.Overall I found it very watchable.  I like Jude Law, but I thought this movie could have used a more traditional hero, someone who would naturally make us think "hero". I'd like to have seen it made with Brendan Fraser.  That's kind of what the movie reminded me of more than anything else - it kept bringing in archetypes from the movies to evoke familiar feelings.  I found the ending a trifle anticlimactic, but it didn't ruin the whole movie for me.

reviewText: If there is one reason to see Sky Captain, it's for the film's amazing visual effects and set designs. It is exactly what eye candy should be; entertaining, beautiful, and often funny. Sky Captain is like a fantasy version of Indiana Jones, and one that is particularly successful.Jude Law stars as the title's Captain, who is now faced with his biggest battle to date. Large robots have invaded the city, destroying everything, unearthing the city's generators. He has to try to put a stop to their plan - and figure out where these flying robots are from - before it's too late.Joining his quest are Polly (Paltrow), a nosy reporter and an old flame of Law's, a scientist pal friend of Law played by Ribbisi and a multitude of funny and original characters. This is one movie that was perfectly cast. Law is perfect as the fearless and smirky Sky Captain, and Paltrow is perfect as the snobbish reporter who will do everything in her power to get what she wants.But see the movie for it's visuals. The whole thing is just like a dream. Having been filmed entirely in front of a blue screen, Sky Captain offers amazing visuals that you won't soon forget. And yes, the effects are well done. The film's washed up Roccocco style is just breathtaking. There is never a dull moment in Sky Captain.I had a great time watching this one. The movie is funny, greatly entertaining and exciting. My only concern is that we'll never see another Sky Captain adventure since the film's box office take was so small. That would be a shame indeed.

reviewText: If you've ever wondered how one of those old science fiction movies or serials with the cheesy props and terrible special effects would look if they were dressed in modern effects and props, your curiosity can now be satisfied. Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow takes the look and scientific incongruity of such old movies and covers them with a thick coat of modern gloss. The look of the movie is incredibly attractive, as are the pretty actors cast in the main roles.Being an homage to such older movies must have provided the movie's creators with a quandry in regards to the plot. If they wanted to  maintain the feel of their inspiration, the plot had to stay light and relatively simple. If they wanted to inspire and captivate the modern audience, they would need to shoehorn in a more complex plot. They chose the former and I'm not sure that was a bad decision. There is only so much a movie like this can accomplish without failing to hit the mark. And it does hit its mark. It is what it aspires to be (a modern remake of an old style and genre).However, I think that a lot of viewers wish it could have been more than it was and, indeed, it doesn't reach levels of greatness because it'd be tough to be both a gripping and compelling story and a good homage to its target.I enjoyed the movie for what it was and felt it was extremely well done. I'd like to give it 3 1/2 stars but the ratings don't allow for that. Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow may be too light a meal for those looking for something with a little more heft but if you're looking for something fun and slightly absurd to watch, you will likely enjoy it.
summary: Beautiful homage to old Sci Fi & serials

reviewText: I was surprised how much I enjoyed this visual feast of a film. The timeframe is 1939-1940 - we know this because we see Polly Parker (Gwenyth Paltrow) viewing "The Wizard of Oz" on the big screen at Radio City Music Hall. She is a sassy professional journalist and amateur photographer in a mostly male-dominated workforce... but it's war time and no one is arguing.The film has almost a dream-like quality of old silver-gum prints that have then been hand-colored. You must see it to appreciate it. Every frame is like the saucy 1940 serials with Art Deco robots and technology.The robots look like Metropolis meets Gort - very artsy-fartsy, yet very ominous at the same time. These are giant 15-story-tall robots, some can fly, and they attack the city, tearing up buildings and streets, leaving with steel and generators, leaving the war-torn nations of the world without materials. No one knows who is behind this until they call Sky Captain (Jude Law) who has his own incredible James Bond-esque plane that can swim under water as well as fly. He and Polly end up trotting across the world, searching for the source of the robots. This same enigma is obviously also behind the disappearance of several of the world's most renowned scientists and no one knows if it's the Russians, the Germans, the Japanese or just some nut that's behind it.Thanks to two lewd comments and constant referral to a supposed incident of cheating on the Sky Captain's part when he was once dating Polly, the innocent, time-capsule quality of the film is lost. If just these few little scenes were snipped (all adding up to about 45 seconds), the film would be a timeless classic. I don't want to give up the plot of the film, but it's an interesting sci-fi genre from the time in which it emulates.This film is an epic achievement on a grand scale and a feast for the eyes and the nostalgic. I highly recommend it.
summary: snip two scenes and it becomes a timeless classic

reviewText: Wow! What a fantastic movie and a genuine achievement in special effects Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow is. The marriage of CGI and live action is seamless, and its saturated colours and striking production design make it one of the most visually stunning films I have ever seen. From start to explosive finish I was riveted to the television screen, and alas, it made me wish I had only gone to see it while at my local cinema. Sky Captain is fast paced and exiting with a great cast of A Grade actors and actresses, and a good script. It has a vibrant and decidedly retro aesthetic that perfectly captures the look, feel and spirit of pulp science fiction from the 1930s and 40s. With its fearless heroes and heroines, giant robots, ray guns and rocket ships inspired by the likes of Buck Rogers or Flash Gordon, it is a true escapists delight. And to think it is brought to life almost entirely with cutting edge 21st Century technology in a truly breathtaking, elegant and stylish way. It's hard to believe that the star studded cast had only a minimal amount of props to work with... amazing!The Art Deco and Streamlined Moderne look of the film was for me a major part of its appeal with its subtle references to important industrial designers and architects from that bygone interwar era. We follow our heroes; Joe Sullivan (Jude Law) and Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow) on a globetrotting adventure that takes them from a mythical and idealized modern metropolis (New York) that is under siege by an army of giant robots, to an exotic Shangri-La (Tibet) high, high up in the Himalayas. We then travel to the bottom of the ocean to confront the evil genius Dr. Totenkopf in his secluded island lair, the apparent source of the mechanical mayhem; for it is he who is plotting to destroy the world which he believes has become morally bankrupt and irredeemably decadent, and must be stopped by our daring heroes at all costs.While the plot is silly, predictable and formulaic and the acting a little too stiff and wooden, remember, Sky Captain is not an "art film" but an entertaining and over the top flight of fancy. The movie is also admittedly quite derivative; especially in terms of the Indiana Jones franchise and the computer game Crimson Skies, but this really doesn't detract from the film which is exceptionally well made (for a first time director) and extremely enjoyable. Something I find hard to fathom is that Sky Captain failed at the box office, for while not the best film I have ever seen, the extraordinary graphic quality and innovative presentation alone should have given it a high measure of success... and let's face it there are far worse movies being made out there today. So if you enjoy good old fashioned action-adventure movies in the vein of King Kong, The Mummy or Indiana Jones, Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow is for you. And even though it might not have much depth, it truly does have heart! So please don't be put off by the bad reviews; for in my humble opinion it is definitely one of the best films to be made in its genre for some years, and I look forward to the special edition DVD.

If you want an old fashioned good time at the movies this is the one you've been waiting for!

reviewerName: Sir Charles Panther "Life is hard.  It's hard...
reviewText: So much promise, and yet so many, many things that just had me at first whispering "No," then shaking my head, then asking all kinds of questions, and finally just wishing for it to be over.  I wanted so badly to dig this film, to really get into it and enjoy it, and by even the mid-point I couldn't help but catalog all of the confusion, contradiction, questions, and junk thrown into and onto this story and film.  It was a significant let-down.On the plus side:- I didn't pay to see it in a theater.- Some very cool general visuals, mainly the backgrounds and panoramic shots of the city, the island, the Shangri-La valley, the robots inside the city, the Union Jack-spangled aerial aircraft carriers, etc.  Beautiful artistic vision.- Neat story, idea, and general sci-fi approach.- Both Law and Jolie had excellent characters to work with, and it looks like they were having fun.On the negative side:- Complete abrogation of the laws of physics.- Dull, washed-out colors, sometimes even looking like bad, early 90s colorization.- New York City doesn't have a massive, snow-capped mountain range within 30 miles of the city.- What exactly is the time frame here, and how have we gotten to a 1940-ish world in which Nazi Germany, expansionist Japan, and World War II have not come to pass?  This is a pretty huge aspect of the story, driving a good part of the action, and would benefit from a modicum of explanation.- How come the good ol' USA is allowing a major privately operated global mercenary force (the Sky Captain's private little group) to occupy space and conduct military major military acquisition, training, and operations within its borders?- Where were the armed forces of the USA in all of this action, especially the attack on NYC?- If Sky Captain runs a global mercenary force, who are they fighting for, and for what goals/objectives?- The street confusion/panic during the robot attack on the city was screamingly inadequate.- How can a 1940s vintage fighter aircraft power-dive a good 10,000 feet and smash into the ocean and not be obliterated into tiny little chips of metal and paint, yet go shooting through the ocean completely unaffected?- How is it the bullets of the robot aircraft stitch-up Law's fighter, but he still flies the living hell out of it, dives it into the ocean, flies it up and out of the ocean, and home?- How come only the Sky Captain's plane managed to get off the ground in the robot attack?  Doesn't he train his people?- How do our heroes manage to outrun an explosion of a few dozen tons of dynamite inside the contained space of an abandoned uranium mine, and then manage to suffer no contamination effects?- What exactly is the doomsday device that is going to incinerate the world, and how is it tied to the rocket ship?- How schmaltzy is it that they had to let all of the animals in the rocket ship loose?  What kind of humans in 1940 had even the slightest inkling of the concept of conservation?- Gwyneth Paltrow may have won an Oscar, but in this movie, describing her performance as "wooden," "hollow," "monotonic," or even "flat" would be very high praise indeed.- Ribisi came off like a sycophantic little nerd.- If one of the kidnapped scientists was so hot that he could build miniature elephants in his home lab, how is it none of that technology ever got out to the larger world?  This is essentially a very lame "Spy Kids 2" leftover.- What in the world do the manufactured dinosaurs on Totenkopf's island have to do with anything in the film?- In the ultimate, gag-inducing plot device, Ribisi has already stolen an anti-gravity barge of some sort, and everyone just escapes, shooting maybe 60mph down a tunnel for a good minute.  Then Sky Captain goes back on his suicide mission as the barge zaps down the tunnel some more, maybe a total of about 2 miles away from where they started.  And yet, only 40 seconds later, there's Paltrow saving Law's butt on the big, scary catwalk.  That would mean that Paltrow could run somewhere around 180mph-wow!- Okay, Ribisi and the liberated scientists are two-odd miles away straight down the escape tunnel, and they find Totenkopf's lab, with the windows looking right out into the rocket bay, from which they just escaped.  Uh, slight bending of logic here.- Law and Paltrow blow the bottom of the rocket out to let all the animals loose, and the rocket is essentially empty-so where is the fricking fuel to power the thing?- Once they empty out the rocket, why don't the atmospheric and aerodynamic forces of a rocket traveling at escape velocity over 50,000 meters in the air rip the rocket to shreds?- First there's only one aerial aircraft carrier, and it's hinted that the existence of it is a major secret, but at the end of the film there must be about a dozen of them in the sky, having arrived at the Totenkopf island in the space of what, maybe about 2-3 hours?  Weak.- Jolie's prop-driven aerial aircraft carrier takes a direct hit to one of the four main engines, yet an hour later for the big finale, it's all fixed up and working just fine.- What exactly was in the oh-so-important vials which were needed so badly?In conclusion, rent it for the pretty pictures, and for a cutting-edge example of the future of digital filmmaking and effects.  But don't expect logic, continuity, or coherence.  It's sci-fi, sure, but this sci-fi effort sadly throws out physics, time, and space in order to fit its poorly constructed, device-dependent story.
summary: Sky Captain and the World of Incredible Disappointment

reviewText: So this is a movie that has a complete feel of the 30's in the way is acted and kind of in the way is shot, it is very reminiscing of those serials ( like Flash Gordon) that star wars was trying to be like, but turned out to be to epic to capture.It is shot completely digitally giving the movie a certain "feel" making it  more like a cartoon in some scenes, but that is beside the point, or perhaps more the point because, like mentioned before, it is supposed to be like one of those old serials which where done in that same light, and with that same kind of acting sometimes. everything from the technology that the characters use to the way they talk is very post WWII pop-America and it is captured well.the plot is also very fantastic and what was usually written about in the times in which movies like this where being made, but the only thing that takes it out of that kind of context is the sometimes too complicated technology that the plane that Sky Captain (Jude Law) gets from his plane, and how tremendously evolved it is, since usually in those serials the people would be in a future time with amazing technology, or deal with the  treats with usual stuff they had around.The designs for this movie are also very reminiscing of the times, with robots that appear to be right out  of the Superman 40's cartoons!I recommend this movie if you have a love for classic simple concept stories told fantastically, with great effects and fun in the acting and action!

reviewText: I remember all of the hype about the merging of computer technology & filmmaking back when FINAL FANTASY - THE SPIRIT WITHIN came out in 2001, but, unlike that film, SKY CAPTAIN AND THE WORLD OF TOMORROW truly will be a milestone in the history of cinema. Rather than trying to replace live actors with less satisfying CGI ones, this film harnesses the promise of computer SPFX to compliment the live performances, and to create a whole new world for the living actors to inhabit...a much more productive approach, IMO.The digital magic created for this film is stunning. Director Kerry Conran and his crew have launched a whole new school of filmmaking, and in the process, a film that is unlike anything that has come before it.Even if everything else in this movie had failed, the computer generated look of this film alone would have been an impressive accomplishment, but, luckily, this film also succeeded on all other levels for me as well; writing, acting, direction, art design, etc.From it's "Elseworld" pseudo-1930's milieu, to it's old school pulp storytelling, to it's stunning art direction and visual detail, this is a film that succeeds on all levels, and should have been a much bigger success when it played in theaters.Jude Law shines as the high flying hero Sky Captain, demonstrating both humor and heroism. Gwyneth Paltrow sparkles as ace reporter and wise-cracking love interest Polly Perkins. And, Angelina Jolie makes the most of her small supporting role (wearing a tight black uniform and sporting an eye-patch I might add) as Frankie, the "other woman" in Sky Captain's past.The films also boasts enjoyable performances by Giovanni Ribisi, Michael Gambon , Ling Bai as "The Mysterious Woman ", and even Laurence freakin' Olivier as the villain, Dr. Totenkopf...and that's quite an accomplishment when you remember that Sir Larry has been dead since 1989 (man, isn't technology amazing?!?).The story is filled with humor, action, "gee whiz" moments a plenty, and I am now even more upset that I never got to see this groundbreaking film up on the big screen during it's initial theatrical release.So, what I guess I am saying is...BUY THIS FILM ON DVD TODAY!!!
summary: An amazing film...and an amazing accomplishment!

reviewText: This film came out a few years before the famed 300 movie by graphic novelist Frank Miller and a year before Frank Miller's Sin City who were both shot on green screen backgrounds.  Entirely shot on green screen backgrounds.  I remember watching this movie when it first came out and hardly heard any buzz over the way the movie was made and how none of the scenes were shot on location anywhere except for on some Hollywood studio lot. I didn't too much care of the way it was made to fully appreciate it.  I just went to the theater with a friend expecting to see another action movie.  Well that's what I got. Cinematically though, it was a true gem.It was only after watching 300 that I remembered about this movie and could have sworn that it was shot in similar fashion, and low and behold it sure was.  Boy, what an entertaining way to make a vintage-looking film without all that production value behind expensive movie sets and expensive trips to different destinations across the world.  It really deserves a second or third go around to fully appreciate today's cinematic technology and how we can easily still enjoy a movie if we suspend reality a bit, as long as the story is entertaining and tickles our imagination.The storyline is of course not believable, that's why this movie should fall under the Fantasy/Sci-Fi genre, but without a doubt it is still an entertaining story and look at a world of yesteryear and what many foretellers would truly see as the world of tomorrow.  Robots, mad-scientists, and hidden islands with prehistoric animals running amuck.  Man's imagination of the future.So before you go hailing 300 as the future of movie-making, you should check out Sky Captain and The World of Tomorrow and appreciate it for its nostalgic feel and much better acting than that of a few greased up hulking Spartans.

reviewText: The opening robot attack had me agog with delight, reminding me of the old "Mars Attacks" bubble gum cards, as well as old favorite movies like "Kronos" and "War of the Worlds" (whose ray gun sound effects are utilized here). After the robots leave, however, the movie kind of drags. Although the visual effects are worthy of the phrase "like nothing you've ever seen," there's an overall darkness to the picture that doesn't let up, even when strolling through supposedly idyllic Shangri-La. But the poorest aspect of the film is the human element, or lack thereof. The characters are somewhat less than two dimensional. Law and Paltrow play their parts very low key, if not somnabulistic, and Ribisi's character has no personality at all. The addition of Laurence Olivier's ghost is pointless. And apart from one milk of magnesia gag, which gave me short-lived hopes for engaging, ironic characters a la "Raiders of the Lost Ark," the people in this movie never do anything human: they don't smoke, drink, eat, look in a mirror...They are merely ciphers there to move the plot along at a sketchy, breakneck pace. Nevertheless, I still enjoyed this mix of retro nostalgia and CGI-candy. I also enjoyed the many allusions, which included, apart from those already mentioned in other reviews here, "King Kong," "Lost Horizon," "Iron Giant," and even "Godzilla." The DVD is flawless. The gag reel is an unfunny waste of time. And if you like "Sky Captain," try "The Rocketeer" if you haven't already.

reviewText: Rumbling to life like the mechanical men that invade a fantasy New York City of the past, "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" is the kind of rip-snorting adventure that, dare I say it, they just don't make anymore.That said, it's far from perfect, with stale and predictable writing and leads Jude Law and Gwyneth Paltrow being not quite charismatic enough to distract us from watching the production, itself at once both truly amazing and irritatingly familiar.  In fact, it's pretty easy to see the influences on "Sky Captain" -- from those that are acknowledged, like "Buck Rogers," to those that aren't, like "The Mysterians," "The Wizard of Oz," Max Fleischer's "Superman" cartoons, "When Worlds Collide," "Raiders of the Lost Ark," Gerry Anderson's various TV series, and more.As derivative as it is, "Sky Captain" unfolds with an exuberant, child-like grace.  No, we don't really believe that a tricked-out P-40 can do all of the things that this one can, any more than we believe that dead Lawrence Olivier was somehow resurrected for one more role.  But the first half hour of "Sky Captain" is so fast-paced, cut and framed like a bona fide film from the 1930s, that it's easy to forgive the lapses in reason - or the standard effort to make a female character "strong" by making her mouthy and impulsive or a male character sensitive by having him put up with it.  Eventually, the film's editing and pacing synch up with more contemporary films, which is a shame, really.The plot is relatively simple, if hard to swallow:  giant robots begin looting cities while a team of scientists, each connected to a mysterious inventor named "Totenkopf," are assassinated one by one.  When all else fails, Sky Captain (Law, looking like the love child of Timothy Dalton and Ewan MacGregor) and his private air force are called in, reuniting the hero with - great Caeser's ghost - a plucky reporter (big-footed Paltrow) a former lover (sexy, one-eyed Angelina Jolie), and his inventor friend, Dex (Giovanni Ribisi, here a poor man's Mickey Rooney).  Of course, the mystery sends them globetrotting, and what they find may make them wish they could just click their heels and be home again.The best thing about "Sky Captain" is the production design, which is a marvel of computer-generated sets and gadgets mixed in with live action from the cast.  Director and writer Kerry Conran definitely has more of an eye for the look of the film than for the script, as he falls into the standard contemporary motif of having characters who should be working together nonetheless (yawn) bicker in the most absurd of situations.  In this film, it's a "Star Wars"-like race through dangerous corridors of air space framed by Gotham's skyscrapers.  And, like a lot of other filmmakers today dodging the pesky issues of a lack of diversity/stereotyping in their works, he gets mileage out of setting the film in the past and making Asians and thinly-veiled Nazis the bad guys -- you know, just like many U.S. and British films of the period.Nonetheless, "Sky Captain" is worth a look, though be warned:  If you don't fall immediately in love with Ed Shearmur's "Sky Captain" theme, you'd better put a bucket over your head and hit it with a wooden spoon `cause that ditty's pretty much played all through the film.

reviewText: I call this a "guilty pleasure" because I don't actually think it's a great movie. But I love the way it looks. And this blu ray transfer doesn't disappoint. The film was shot very diffused, so nothing is super-clear, whether DVD or blu ray. But the movie's innovative visual style – and visual effects – are so intriguing that I still thought it was worth owning on blu ray.As for the movie itself, it was a little weak on plot and, truth be told, Gwyneth Paltrow's character was awfully annoying. But it was so cool looking that, again, weak plot and characters just didn't seem to matter. If you have any affection whatsoever for this film, buy this blu ray disc.

reviewText: Kerry Conran's "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" is a visually-stunning tribute to the science-fiction films of yesteryear.  Yet, when you get past the breathtaking production design, you find yourself watching a film that is just a smidge more sophisticated than those Commando Cody shorts that used to air on "Mystery Science Theater 3000."Joe "Sky Captain" Sullivan (Jude Law) is always there to save the day whenever danger threatens.  He is reunited with old flame Polly Perkins (Gwyneth Paltrow) when giant robots invade Manhattan.  It turns out that the robots are part of a dastardly plan conceived by the mysterious Doctor Totenkopf (Laurence Olivier).  With the help of Franky Cook (Angelina Jolie), the captain of a British airship, Joe and Polly set out to defeat the villainous mastermind.If the story of "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" seems bare-boned, it is because it is bare-boned.  Conran apparently was not content with just recreating the look and feel of the science-fiction films of the past.  He also duplicates the pedestrian scripts and one-dimensional characters that characterized the more cheesy entries in the genre.  It is too bad that such a tepid screenplay undermines all the hard work done to give "Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow" its distinctive look.  Law, Paltrow, and Jolie do their best but they are trapped in a film that completely disregards substance in its pursuit of style.
summary: "Polly Perkins.  I've heard so much about you.  It's a pleasure to finally meet the competition."

reviewText: I've been waiting a long, long time for a movie like this. A long, LONG, time. But finally my prayers have been answered. Is Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow the steam-punk, retro-futuristic, CGI-candy, dream-come-true that everyone has been hoping and wishing for? All that and a box of everlasting-gobstoppers.The first thing that people will notice about this film is it's eye-popping visuals. Anyone who has had the pleasure of seeing Mamoru Oshii's film Avalon will be familiar with the style. It's hard to describe exactly, but you'll know it when you see it. Everything has a soft focus, and a noir-ish black and a cool retro, almost black-and-white-but-not-quite tint. Some will say this is to cover up the CGI and blue screens. Personally I think it's to create a cool visual effect. Not that there aren't CGI and blue screens...This film has got to have more CGI than any other film in history. That's because EVERYTHING is computer-generated, from the cities, to the skies, to the giant mechanical monsters. Normally I hate CGI usage in films (like in Spiderman or Star Wars), but in this film the CGI is not an effect. It is the entire film. As such it isn't part of the movie so much as it permeates it. It doesn't look fake because the entire film is like an incredible dream you might have if you remembered every cool Hollywood film you grew up with as a kid. And speaking of cool Hollywood films...This movie is super-charged with the same spirit of adventure that made everything from the Adventures of Robin Hood and Captain Blood to Star Wars and Indiana Jones the great films that they are. Watching Sky Captain maneuver his plane through the city streets is exhilarating in the same way that an X-Wing fighter was the first time we saw it head down the Deathstar trench. Don't get the wrong idea, however. This movie in no way feels like it's stealing from great films of the past. Rather, it is a fresh creation born from the spirit, ideals, and idealism of its forerunners (and there's no such thing as an original idea anyway, or at least that's what Isaac Asimov said). The best way I can convey what this film is about is to remind you of movies like The Fifth Element and anime series like The Big O and Giant Robo. These combined old ideas in a new way, sharing the spirit of yesteryear with a whole new generation.Some complain that there isn't much in the way of plot to be found in this picture, and perhaps they are right. I could describe the story of the first Star Wars film in one sentence. I could describe the Prisoner of Zenda in a few more. In other words, good adventure films often HAVE NO PLOT! That's their trademark, really (anyone remember Kurosawa's classic The Hidden Fortress?)Although the action sequences are glorious, and the visuals are breath-taking (going from the aforetomentioned Noir style in the beginning to a mind-blowing explosion of color towards the end), no movie can truly be great without appealing characters and a story that holds your attention. Now I've never been a big fan of Angelina Jolie or Gwyneth Paltrow, but I've always loved Jude Law. That said, I feel that everyone who was in this film gave a great performance, nailing the character they were playing perfectly. Sky Captain is a total Errol Flynn type character and his essence is captured perfectly by Jude Law. Polly Perkins is a wonderful Lios Lane type played wonderfully by Gwyneth Paltrow. And it's a good thing Angelina Jolie is in so little of the movie because she pretty much steals the show with her wonderful portrayal of Frankie Cook.The musical score of this movie harkens back to the good-old-days of Hollywood, much as do the finest scores of John Williams and James Horner. For what it's worth I loved the musical score, watching all the way through the end credits of the film (and Jane Monheit's mesmerizing new version of "Somewhere Over the Rainbow").Some people like their movies to be realistic. Some people don't like old movies. Some people hate anime, can't stand classic film scores, and don't like cartoons. This movie is not for them. This movie is for the kids who grew up with classic sci-fi and adventure movies, teen-agers who love comic books, and all those who long for the Hollywood days of yesteryear. For what it's worth, I think this is the best film of the year. If more films like this are on the way, it will indeed be a grand and glorious tomorrow!
summary: Look forward to a grand and glorious tomorrow!

reviewText: I generally liked Sky Captain.  It was obviously a labor of love by the creative team and towards the end it came together and felt full enough to be a fun joyride.  Little kids might love this film and I expect it will make some money, but it was less than the sum of it's parts & I felt kind of let down by the time I left the theater.Unfortunately this felt more like a live-action comic book than a movie. Basically there are only 4-5 people in this film, and none of them were able to sustain this juggernaut without more and better dialogue and more humor.  They were trying for Cary Grant 40's style charming banter, but to me it sounded more like the outline of movie dialogue than an actual movie.I also loved the CGI, but the story is full of gigantic, unmanageable plot holes so that I could only barely connect this world to any version of the 30's or 40's.  Things like 'where are the adults?' - is Sky Captain the top authority in the U.S. government?  Don't people usually die when they hit the water at 400mph and sustain a 30G impact? How does one fly from NYC to Nepal without refueling? And so on and on.This type of movie requires an across-the-board suspension of disbelief which I can only grant to transcendent works of Genius, and this just didn't qualify.  It was meant to appear corny and charming like Indiana Jones, but it's just not solid enough.Gwyneth Paltrow who is usually a warm and hypnotizing presence started out as a cool and untrustworthy and self-centered.  She has no vulnerability or quirks or virtues to make her likeable, and she only improves slightly towards the end.Jude Law feels much more solid in his role and he does have Virtue in that he's trying to Save The World, but he's also similarly underwritten.Giovani Ribisi once again has hit the jackpot as a nondescript talentless guy who somehow lands movie roles in Hollywood.Basically nobody asks much from these actors and that's what they deliver. Jude and Gwyneth are both very talented and high-profile. They also have perfect posture & features and look like classic Greek gods in sepia-tone.  It's a pity they couldn't do more with this project.In the end, Sky Captain felt to me like a film school project on steroids. It needed more script and better direction - my sense is that they'd let a 17-year old drive the Ferrari when he should have had a starter-car.  Ultimately it's a misfire which may make money but will end up in the bargain bin.

reviewText: Another classic case of "what it could've been". This film will easily wow you in its opening 10 minutes only to dissapoint you as it progresses. This is ultimately how it will be remembered."Sky Captain..." is based on 30s-40s aesthetics and 50s sci-fi films and it aims to cash in on the nostalgia factor for the old classics. On a visual level it does extremely well. On an intellectual level it does poorly.A plot that borders infantile conception cant possibly be compensated by the awe-inspiring visuals, CGIs, and great cinematography in general. The average western viewer has outgrown that.The old and cliched storyline of an abstract bad guy threatening the world for abstract reasons doesnt wash any more. Not when the good guys are as mindless and simpletonic as the ones portrayed in this film, to the point where a choice as to whom to identify with could be decided through a coin toss.On top of that, a plot with seriously insulting holes as the one here, only makes for further damage on the film's effectivity, especially when these inconsistencies are eye-poking at best and cant be ignored unless you're someone who could ignore stomping elephants in your living room.And as for acting...Well...You cant possibly ask for acting when the actors barely have time to utter some trivial line in-between explosions and air-chases. A very competent actor like Jude Law goes pointlessly wasted in this flick. They could've hired anybody for such a low-expectations job and the the dent on people's reputation participating here would be avoided.But among all this mess, there's the positives that i started of with:the director has done a truly outstanding job capturing the feeling of 50s sci-fi. The fact that he's done it in a hollow manner is the other side of the coin. But he did do great in that sector. It's not only the clever usage of colour that achieved this, but also the carefully depicted "primitive" technology (seeing the hilarious giant robots will convince you of this. This doubled with some well inspired ideas realised by the CGI makes it an optical feast.I'd go as far as say that if you watched this with the voice off you'll be alot more rewarded than otherwise. And less cerebrally insulted.A definitely good try but certainly not worth the cigar.

reviewText: When I first watch its preview in San Diego ComicCon that they have interview with Jude Law and all, I thought its gonna be something really special that capture something from the 70s, and I'm wrong! its freaking boring..  The idea is very unique indeed, but it get raped by the very very poor production. The problem is through the whole movie all you see is the actors running and walking around some still CG background, the camera never actually move a bit so you see more detail of where they are, I take one scene for example, the cave they walk into at teh end, one second they spot it at teh outside 20 yard from the entrance, hold still for a while , the next second the shot taken they already inside walking deep in, there arent even a single frame describe how they get there from where they landed, such kindda details skipping problems are all over the movie. While everything is computerized they dun spend enough effort to design everything, many of those background are only 1 beautiful still picture and they have never been rendered into motion, which makes the way the movie goes in such an odd way(except for the first 20 mins maybe), 1/2 of the times the audience only gotta see actors are walking or sitting inside somewhere without letting us see whats around them. reviewText: I picked a copy up of this recently, and I remember watching it when it was first released. It is such a tragedy that more people have not seen this and that the director has not made more films since.The biggest problem with Sky Captain is the opening, it is too slow and a little dull. However, once the robots invade and the action cranks a gear - this becomes a brilliant film - mad scientists, crazy robots and flying contraptions, then there are some really great performances.I say great performances, as all the actors are playing up there characters as a tribute to the bygone day of television science fiction serials. If you're ever had the pleasure of watching the original black and white tv show of the Rocketeer then you will know exactly what the director was aiming for.I think enough has been said about the effects - they are superb and the techniques have since been used to great effect in many other films. If you enjoyed the style of 300 by Zack Snyder, then you are going to love this film.The film has a lot of flaws, and we're left wondering when we will see a great steam punk style movie - anyone any reccomendations - after this and also the league of extraordinary gentlemen did not attract a wider audience.
